mainData.point1: Respiration takes place in all living things
mainData.point2: Respiration is a process by which energy is released from glucose or other organic substances to carry out life processes.
mainData.point3: Energy is required for growth, repair, movement or other metabolic activities.
mainData.point4: The process of cellular respiration converts glucose into energy needed by the cells for growth, reproduction and to carry out cellular functions
mainData.point5: Sugars (glucose) + Oxygen ------> Carbon Dioxide + Water + Energy

mainData.point1: Aerobic Respiration occurs in the presence of oxygen.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: Anaerobic Respiration occurs when there is not enough oxygen available.
mainData.point2: Glucose is only partially broken down and lactic acid is produced.
mainData.point3: A lot less energy is produced and most energy (About 70%) is lost in the form of heat.
mainData.point4: When Anaerobic Respiration occurs in yeast, it is called fermentation.
mainData.point5: Water + Carbon Dioxide ----(Sunlight + Chlorophyll)---> Sugars (Glucose) + Oxygen

mainData.point1: Plants are the only organisms that create their own food. They create their own food through a process called Photosynthesis.
mainData.point2: During photosynthesis, plants convert light energy to chemical energy, and get sugars and oxygen in exchange.
mainData.point3: Carbon Dioxide enters the leaves through openings known as the stomata during the day. The stomata is found mostly on the underside of the leaves. During gaseous exchange, the stomata will open and close, allowing gases to enter and leave the plant. A chemical reaction will occur when the carbon dioxide combines with the stored energy (sunlight) to produce sugars.

mainData.point1: The sugars made by the plant during photosynthesis are stored as starch.
mainData.point2: The sugars are stored in different places, such as roots, stems, leaves and fruits in plants that can bear fruits.

mainData.point1: In a food chain, energy flows from the Sun to the plants, and from the plants to animals further in the food chain.
mainData.point2: The food chain progresses by, Producers → Primary Consumers → Secondary Consumers → Tertiary Consumers → Apex Predators

mainData.point1: Plants are also called producers in a food chain as they help produce food for animals further in the food chain.
mainData.point2: Plants have unlimited energy as they get their energy from the sun as light.

mainData.point1: Herbivores are plant eaters.
mainData.point2: They have the ability to digest the plants they eat and release the energy stores in the plant cells for their own use.

mainData.point1: Carnivores are meat eaters
mainData.point2: Predators and scavengers fall into this group. They eat animals that eat plants, also known as Herbivores or Carnivores.

mainData.point1: Omnivores are animals that eat both plants and animals.
mainData.point2: For example, some examples of omnivores are humans, bears, turtles, monkeys.

mainData.point1: Decomposers are animals that feed on dead plants or animals, which break down the dead plants and animals into simple substances that would be returned to the environment
mainData.point2: Made up mostly of bacteria and fungi.

mainData.point1: Apex Predators are predators that are at the end of the food chain, and eat most organisms
mainData.point2: An Example of an Apex Predator is humans.

mainData.point1: Energy is the ability to do work.
mainData.point2: All of the energy used by humans on earth comes either directly or indirectly from the sun.
mainData.point3: We use the energy directly from the sun, when we use things like solar panels to capture the light energy from the sun.
mainData.point4: We use the energy indirectly from the sun, when we eat plants whom get their energy and food from the sun by photosynthesis.

mainData.point1: Close your eyes and imagine what it would be like to live in a world without light. Firstly, we would not be able to see things and if you try to move around, you would most probably fall over things. Next, colour and beauty would be absent in a world without light. Thus, we see how important light is to us.
mainData.point2: We see things every day, from the moment we get up in the morning till we go to bed at night. We look at everything around us using light such as enjpying the rainbow in the sky and the fine drawings at the art gallery. Light from the Sun, rising above the horizon in the east, gives shape, detail and colour to our world.
mainData.point3: Light is a form of energy that can also be used to do work besides enabling us to see things around us. For example, man-made satellites and probes make use of light energy to function. They have structures called solar cells which trap light energy for their use.

mainData.point1: All light must come from a light source. A light source is any object that gives off light on its own.

mainData.point1: A light source can be natural or artificial.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: Some animals, such as fireflies and glow-worms, are natural light sources which make their own light to attract mates.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: Note that not all things that shine are light sources. There is a difference between a light source that emits its own light and an object that reflects light from a light source.

mainData.point1: The Moon shines but it is not a source of light because it reflects light from the Sun.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: A mirror is also not a source of light because it does not make its own light, it just reflects light.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: There are four important properties of light to take note.
mainData.point2: Light travels in a straight line. This explains why we cannot see things round the bend of corners.
mainData.point3: Light can be reflected. This explains why we can see objects which are not sources of light around us. The light falls on these objects reflects light into our eyes.
mainData.point4: Light can be absorbed. This explains how shadows are formed. When light cannot pass through opaque objects like wood or metal (when the objects block the path of light), a shadow of the object will be formed.
mainData.point5: Light can be transmitted. If light goes through an object, it is said to be transmitted. This explains why we can see through glass, air and water clearly.

mainData.concepts: What happens when light strikes an object?
mainData.point1: When light rays travel and strike a surface, they may be reflected, transmitted or absorbed.
mainData.point2: When light is reflected, most of the objects around us are not sources of light. They are called non-luminous objects. These objects only reflect light, which means when light falls on these objects, it bounces off them. The light that bounces off these objects travels to our eyes and enables us to see them.
mainData.point3: This explains why we cannot see anything, not even our fingers, in a pitch-dark room. As there is no light source in the dark room, no light will fall on the objects in the room. Hence, no light will be reflected from them and we are not able to see anything.
mainData.point4: All objects reflect light. Animals, plants, fungi and non-living things reflect light. The amount and direction of the reflected light depend on the type of surface it strikes. Smooth and shiny surfaces reflect light better than rough and dull ones. For example, steel spoons and aluminium foil can reflect light much better than dark-coloured towels and charcoal.
mainData.point5: The reflection of light from a smooth surface is called a regular reflection. When light falls on the smooth surface, it bounces off at matching angles which results in a reflection.
mainData.point6: However, when a surface is rough or unpolished, the light rays that fall on it are reflected or scatthered in all directions. We call this a diffused reflection.

mainData.concepts: When light is transmitted or absorbed, besides reflection, light rays that fall on objects can also be transmitted or absorbed. We say that these objects are transparent, translucent or opaque.
mainData.point1: Some objects allow light to pass through like glass. These objects are transparent.
mainData.point2: Some objects like frosted glass transmits part of the light that falls on it, so we cannot see them clearly. These objects are translucent.
mainData.point3: These objects like wood does not allow light to go through. If it is not reflected on the object, some light is absorbed. The amount of light an object absorbs depends on the object's surface. Rough and black surfaces are better light absorbers than white and shiny surfaces. These objects are opaque.
mainData.point4: Thus, when light strikes an object, it will react in one or more of the ways mentioned above, depending on whether the object is transparent, translucent, opaque, smooth, rough or glossy.

mainData.point1: Opaque objects do not allow light to go through them. When light falls on an opaque object, it cannot bend and go around the object since light travels in a straight line. Thus the object, which blocks the path of light, casts a shadow. A shadow is, therefore, an area of darkness that is formed when an object blocks the path of light

mainData.point2: The presence of a light source
mainData.point3: The presence of an object to block the light
mainData.point4: The presence of a surface or screen that light can fall on

mainData.point4: The shape of the shadow resembles the outline of the object that casts the shadow

mainData.point2: When the light source is nearer the object, the size of the shadow increases.
mainData.point3: When the light source is further away from the object, the size of the shadow decreases.
mainData.point4: When the object is nearer to the screen, the size of the shadow decreases
mainData.point5: When the object is further away from the screen, the size of the shadow increases.

mainData.point1: The position of the Sun relative to the Earth is always changing because the Earth completes one full rotation every 24 hours.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: Day occurs when our side of the Earth faces the Sun and night occurs when our side faces away.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: We notice that shadows cast by the Sun move. This is because the Sun appears to move in the sky. The constant turning of the Earth in front of the Sun, which is stationary relative to us, gives the impression that the Sun is moving from east to west every day. Hence, the Sun's rays also change in direction and shadows are formed in different places.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: Observing the shadows made by the Sun during the course of a day provides information about time: the times of midday sunrise and sunset.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: Noon or midday is the time of day when the shadow that the Sun casts is the shortest. The shadow will be longest early and late in the day.

mainData.point1: Before there were clocks, people used shadows to tell time. By looking at the length and position of the shadow, we can tell the time of the day. In fact, sundials (or shadow clocks) have been used to tell time for many centuries. They make use of the changing positions of the Sun to tell time. The diagram below enables us to understand how the shadow of an object in a sunny place changes at different times of the day.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: Today, most people who have sundials use them for decoration rather than as a way of keeping time. Sundials could still be counted on to keep accurate time, and they were often used to set the time on clocks that had stopped! The sundial was still the most popular way of keeping time until watches were invented, making it easier for people to tell time wherever they were.

mainData.point1: Heat
mainData.point2: Is invisible (cannot be seen) but can be felt. 1. Is a form of energy and is an essential part of everyday life.
mainData.point3: Is needed to do work like cooking, ironing and driving engines.
mainData.point4: Can cause changes in the of matter, for example, from ice to water.
mainData.point5: Always flows from a hotter object to a colder object.
mainData.point6: Can change the temperature of an object.

mainData.point1: Anything that gives off heat is a source of heat. Most sources of light are also sources of heat
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: Some examples of sources of heat are listed below
mainData.point2: Heat from the Sun
mainData.point3: If we have been out on a hot day, we would have felt the heat from the Sun
mainData.point4: The Sun is our main source of heat and light.
mainData.point5: The Sun's energy is known as solar energy and plants make use of this solar energy for photosynthesis
mainData.point6: Man makes use of the Sun's heat to dry wet clothes and to preserve food.
mainData.point7: Solar heaters make use of the Sun's heat to make the water hot.

mainData.point1: Heat from fuels
mainData.point2: A fuel is anything which burns to produce energy. • Examples of fuels are kerosene, wood and gas.
mainData.point3: Fuels burn to give off heat and light. Heat from electricity
mainData.point4: A metal wire gets very hot when electricity passes through it.
mainData.point5: he electrical energy has been changed to heat energy.
mainData.point6: Some metals release more heat than others when electricity passes through them. For example, iron releases more heat than copper.
mainData.point7: In order for electricity to be used as a source of heat, we must first produce electricity.
mainData.point8: Man has learned to use electricity to produce heat in many household appliances for different purposes. Examples include the water heater and the iron.

mainData.point1: Heat from friction
mainData.point2: When we rub our hands together for 30 seconds and then place our palms on our cheeks, the heat that we feel is the result of friction.
mainData.point3: Heat is produced when two objects are rubbed together and the objects become warm in this process of rubbing due to friction.
mainData.point4: Cavemen started fires by rubbing two sticks or stones together and when they do that, kinetic (movement) energy is converted to heat energy.
mainData.point5: Often, lubricants, such as oil, are used to decrease friction and the amount of heat created in machines.

mainData.point1: Heat from chemical reaction
mainData.point2: Chemical reactions occur every day all around us. A chemical reaction is a process where one type of substance is chemically converted another substance.
mainData.point3: Chemical reactions can produce heat in a number of ways.
mainData.point4: For example, oxygen in the air reacts with the charcoal in a barbecue grill and produces heat and light.
mainData.point5: Sugar when heated breaks down into carbon and water vapour and produces heat in the process.
mainData.point6: The rusting of iron and the digestion of food are also chemical reactions that give off heat. For example, chemical reactions that occur in digestion give off heat that keeps our bodies warm and functioning

mainData.point1: We use heat in many ways, both at home and in industries as shown
mainData.point2: Uses of heat
mainData.point8: Heat from burning cool can help to generate electricity in a power plant
mainData.point9: Heat is used to make or process food, glass, paper and textiles
mainData.point10: Heat is used to melt, shape, cut and harden metals.

mainData.point1: We experience temperature every day. When it is very hot outside or when we have a fever, we feel hot and when it is raining and windy outside, we feel cold. We feel hot or cold depending on the environment around us and our recent experiences.
mainData.point2: Knowing the temperature of things can be very important. Cooks may need to know when the turkey is fully cooked, or parents might have to make sure that a child is not running a fever. In laboratory testing, precise measurements of temperatures are required frequently in experiments.
mainData.point3: Temperature is not energy, but a measure of it.
mainData.point4: Temperature is a measure of the degree of hotness or coldness of matter. Usually we feel an object with our hands to find out how hot or how cold the object is. However, this is not a good method to measure temperature.
mainData.point5: The human sense of touch is not an accurate measure of the degree of hotness and coldness, and it is sometimes dangerous to rely on this method. An extremely cold object may cause frostbite while an extremely hot object may scald us.
mainData.point6: Temperature does not depend on the size or type of object. For example, the temperature of a small cup of boiling water is the same as the temperature of a large pot of boiling water even if the large pot is much bigger than the cup.
mainData.point7: When people want to detect illness, or attempt scientific testing, various types of thermometers are available to serve the different purposes.

mainData.point1: Many devices have been invented to accurately measure temperature. These devices have a temperature scale which transform the measurement of temperature into meaningful numbers.
mainData.point2: Thermometers or data loggers (as shown in the diagrams below) are some examples of instruments used to measure the temperature of an object accurately.
mainData.point3: A data logger is a device that can store measurements made bu an electronic sensor. It can record temperature measurements every tenth of a second and can continue recording data automatically, sometimes for days. The information in the data logger can be downloaded into a computer where the results can be analysed and graphs can be drawn using computer software.
mainData.point4: A commonly used thermometer is the laboratory thermometer. It is often used in science laboratories to measure temperature.

mainData.point1: The markings on the thermometer tell us the level of the liquid. To read the temperature, we look at the level of the liquid and note the marking nearest to it. The marking shows the temperature in degree Celsius.
mainData.point2: The end of tube is sealed.
mainData.point3: The glass tube is filled with either alcohol or mercury. Mercury is a silvery liquid and alcohol is colourless. When alcohol is used in thermometers, it is usually coloured red to make it visible.
mainData.point4: . A thermometer is made of a glass tube with a spherical or cylindrical bulb at one end.

mainData.point1: The unit of temperature measurement we will be learning is the degree Celsius. On the Celsius scale
mainData.point2: The number '0' is the temperature at which pure water freezes normal atmospheric pressure.
mainData.point4: The number '100' is the temperature at which pure water boils at normal atmospheric pressure
mainData.point5: The space in between 0 and 100 is divided into a hundred equal parts. Each part is called a degree Celsius.
mainData.point6: The symbol "C' is used to indicate degree Celsius.

mainData.point1: To measure the temperature of a matter using a thermometer, you should:
mainData.point2: Place the bulb of the thermometer into the matter.
mainData.point3: Watch the liquid level of the thermometer rise or drop, depending on the temperature of the matter.
mainData.point4: Wait for the liquid level to stabilise before reading the temperature.
mainData.point5: Ensure that you place your eyes at the liquid level for accurate reading.

mainData.point1: There are different types of thermometers that are used to measure temperature but the type of thermometers used depends on the nature of the matter or substances measured. Various types of thermometers are available today, instead of the traditional mercury thermometers.

mainData.point1: The clinical thermometer is a type of thermometer used to measure our body temperature.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: The liquid used is mercury.
mainData.point2: It has a small temperature range of 35°C to 42°C as the body temperature of a healthy person is about 37°C. This small range enhances the accuracy in the reading of temperature.
mainData.point3: The constriction is a bend very near the bulb in the glass stem. It helps to prevent mercury from returning to the bulb too quickly so as to give us sufficient time to read and reçord the temperature accurately.

mainData.point1: Thermometers are widely used in medicine to check the body for fever. To measure body temperature using the clinical thermometer, you should:
mainData.point2: Shake the thermometer vigorously so as to force the mercury to flow back to the bulb
mainData.point3: Place the thermometer under the tongue or the armpit of the person concerned.
mainData.point4: Read the temperature only after removing the thermometer from the person

mainData.point1: Difference between Heat and Temperature Heat and temperature are entirely two different things. To understand the difference between heat and temperature, we must first understand what heat is. Heat is the amount of energy in a matter that makes it hot, whereas temperature tells us how hot or cold an object
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: Look at the glass of water and the jug of water in the diagram below.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: Both the jug and glass of water are of the same temperature, 90°C. However, the jug of water has more heat in it than the glass of water. This is because more heat is needed to warm the jug of water to 90°C than to warm the glass of water to the same temperature. Therefore, heat and temperature are not the same thing.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: If we take two objects which have the same temperature and put them together, there will be no overall flow of heat between them because they are at the same temperature. But if the temperature of one object is higher than that of the other object, there will be a flow of heat energy from the hotter to the colder object until both objects reach the same temperature.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: There are three important things to know about the way heat flows
mainData.point2: There must be a temperature difference for heat to flow
mainData.point3: Heat flows from a higher temperature to a lower temperature
mainData.point4: The greater or larger the difference in temperature, the faster the heat flows.

mainData.point1: A hotter object always loses heat to a colder object until both are of the same temperature. A practical example to demonstrate flow of heat is the cooling of a cup of hot tea in a basin of tap W as shown below. The hot cup of tea will experience a net heat loss and the cool tap water, a net heat gain as a result of the difference temperature.

mainData.point1: Materials that do not allow heat to travel easily through them are called poor conductors of heat or insulators. Examples include plastics, wood and rubber

mainData.concepts: Uses of Good and Bad conductors of Heat
mainData.point1: Metals usually conduct heat extremely well. This explains the use of iron, copper, aluminium or stainless steel in cooking utensils where direct heating is involved
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Uses of Good and Bad conductors of Heat
mainData.point1: There are some things that we want heat energy to flow through easily. For example, copper is an excellent conductor of heat energy. Pots and pans made of copper transfer heat energy quickly and evenly to the sides of the pan. This helps to get the food cooked evenly throughout. When the pan is removed from its source of heat energy (the stove), it immediately transfers its heat energy to the surrounding air or cools down. This prevents the food from getting overcooked.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Uses of Good and Bad conductors of Heat
mainData.point1: Soldering iron rods are made of iron with the tip made of copper as it is a much better conductor of heat than iron.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Uses of Good and Bad conductors of Heat
mainData.point1: There are utensils in the kitchen that we definitely do not want to gethot For example, oven mittens which are supposed to protect our hands from getting burnt cannot be made of metal. We also would not want cooking spoons, spatulas and even pot handles to get hot. Thus, many of these things are made insulators that limit the transfer of heat. Examples include plastics, wood, rubber, and cloth
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Uses of Good and Bad conductors of Heat
mainData.point1: Bamboo, like all wood, is a poor conductor of heat energy Because they do not transfer heat energy well, bamboo and wood are used to make cutting boards, spoons and serving dishes. Another example is sawdust which is used blocks because of its good insulating property
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Uses of Good and Bad conductors of Heat
mainData.point1: Plastic is a poor conductor of heat energy. Plastics make good cooking utensils, such as spoons to stir sauces and soups, or storage containers for food. Even though plastic does not transfer heat energy well, if enough heat energy is applied to some types of plastic, they melt. Only certain plastics are designed to handle high temperatures. So care must be taken when handling plastics around heat.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Uses of Good and Bad conductors of Heat
mainData.point1: Many types of cookware and kitchen utensils are made from a combination of materials-some that are good conductors of heat energy and others that are poor conductors. Using a combination of materials makes these tools even easier to use in the kitchen. A cooking pot as shown below is an example.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Uses of Good and Bad conductors of Heat
mainData.point1: A cooking pot is made of metal (commonly stainless steel) because heat, which can travel very easily through metal, is needed to cook the food in it.
mainData.point2: The knob of the lid and the handles of the pot are made of wood or plastics because they are poor conductors of heat. They will not get hot easily so we can hold them to lift the lid or carry the pot. They prevent heat from reaching our hands and thus, protect us from getting burnt.
mainData.point3: Cork and cardboard are poor conductors of heat. Hence, they are used as coasters to protect the tabletop from being burnt by hot cooking pots.
mainData.point4: Note that a pot of hot soup on a stove gained heat from the stove via the underside of the pot. The temperature of the soup increases as it gains heat.

mainData.concepts: Uses of Good and Bad conductors of Heat
mainData.point1: Poor conductors of heat take a long time to get heated up and lose heat very slowly to the surroundings. They can thus be used to make a tea cosy or a food container.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Uses of Good and Bad conductors of Heat
mainData.point1: Hot food placed in food containers is kept warm because heat is lost very slowly. Likewise, when cold food is put in these containers, it will be kept cold longer because heat from the surroundings takes a longer time to get in.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Uses of Good and Bad conductors of Heat
mainData.point1: Many materials are poor conductors of heat because they contoin tin pockets of air. Woollen clothing and accessories are worn by people living in temperate countries to keep warm. These woollen materials trap a layer of air in them. The air is then warmed by the body to maintain the body's temperature. Since both the woollen and air are poor conductors of heat, they will help to slow dowe heat loss from our bodies to the cold surroundings and thus, keep us warm
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Uses of Good and Bad conductors of Heat
mainData.point1: Fiberglass and expanded polystyrene foam which trap large amount of air are being used as insulators in the walls of houses, ice boxes one refrigerators. Double glazing is also commonly used as air is a very poor conductor of heat.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Uses of Good and Bad conductors of Heat
mainData.point1: Birds can also use the same principle to keep warm. They fluff up their feathers in cold weather. This action allows air to be trapped in the feathers and cuts down heat loss from their bodies. Instead of using feathers, a polar bear uses its fur to trap air in order to keep warm.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: Most matter expands when they are heated (or when they gain heat) and contracts when they are cooled (or when they lose heat). Thus when a piece of metal is heated, it expands and upon cooling, the metal contracts and tries to resume its original shape
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: Household thermometers also work according to this principle: The mercury a liquid metal in the thermometer held in a hand, rises due to the expansion of the mercury from the heat of the body. If the hand is removed, the mercury level falls due to a contraction.

mainData.point1: Not all materials contract or expand at the same rate. The amount of contraction or expansion varies depending on the material, Some things expand a lot when heated while others expand slightly. A very good example is the bimetallic strip. A bimetallic strip is made of brass on one side and steel on the other. When heated, the bimetallic strip bends because one metal expands more than the other. In this case, the strip curves toward the steel side as shown in the diagram below. When cooled in liquid nitrogen, it curves the other way.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: One of the many uses for bimetallic strips is in electrical breakers where excessive current through the strip heats it and bends it to trip the switch to interrupt the current. Its other applications include thermal switches, electric iron and thermometers.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Uses of expansion and contraction in our daily lives
mainData.point1: The expansion and contraction of matter on heating and cooling respectively con be put to good use in our daily lives as follow
mainData.point2: Opening a tightly screwed bottle cap
mainData.point3: A bottle cap that connot be opened con be immersed in hot water.
mainData.point4: Heat from the hot water will cause the cap to expand.
mainData.point5: The expanded cap, which has become bigger and hence looser, can now be opened quite easily
mainData.point7: A dented ball can be restored to its original shape by pouring hot water over it.
mainData.point8: Heat from the hot water causes the air in the ball to expand.
mainData.point9: The expanded air pushes against the wall of the ball on the inside, bringing it back to its original shape.

mainData.point1: The temperature in our surroundings changes very often. This change in temperature causes structures around us to expand and contract. We must, therefore, make sure that the things around us are designed such that they can accommodate the expansion and contraction of matter
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: The effects of expansion and contraction, if not taken into will cause problems.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: Expansion gaps
mainData.point2: Flyovers, bridges and railway lines have gaps in between them to allow for expansion. In hot weather, these structures expand. If there are no gaps between them, there will be no space for them to expand. Then they will push against each other and bend as result. When that happens, the structures will be damaged and become unsafe for vehicles to travel.

mainData.point1: Sagging telephone lines
mainData.point2: Sagging telephone lines Outdoor overhead electrical wires are hung loosely on poles. If the wires are tightly installed, they would contract and snap in cold weather. If they are put up too loosely, they will sag on a hot day which is both unsightly and dangerous.

mainData.point1: Expansion loops of a pipe
mainData.point2: In factories and industries, pipes are used to carry hot gases, steam and liquids. If there is no room for expansion in such pipes, they will burst. So, most metal pipes have loops at intervals to allow for expansion.

mainData.point1: Air space in containers
mainData.point2: Air space in containers Liquids, such as soft drinks, oil and chemicals, are usually stored in bottles, cans and various types of containers. If the containers are completely filled, expansion of the liquids will cause the container to break or explode. Thus, the containers that are sealed or closed are not filled completely to allow for the expansion of liquids.

mainData.point1: Rollers and sliding joints on metal bridges
mainData.point2: Usually one end of a large bridge is fixed and the opposite end rests on rollers. There is also a sliding joint at the moving end which allows expansion and contraction of the metal bridge.

mainData.point1: Fitting steel tyre to a wheel
mainData.point2: Fitting a steel tyre to a wheel is often done bu first heating them so that they expand. The steel is then made to just fit when it is red hot. As it cools down it tighten its grip on the wheel. No fixing of screws or nails is required. Hot rivets are used to join metal sheets by the same method.

mainData.point1: Flowering plants have two structures
mainData.point2: First, the new plants produce flowers. Flowers allowed the plants to form partnerships with insects. These insects, in exchange for pollen and nectar, greatly increased the efficiency of the pollination of the plants.
mainData.point3: Secondly, the parent plant developed the seed coat on their seeds. Each seed sed in a tough little covering to help it to survive and remain dormant until conditions favour their successful germination and development.

mainData.point1: Generally, a a flower acts as a medium to enable the male and female reproductive cells to fuse in order to produce seeds. The process begins with pollination followed by fertilisation and continues with the formation and dispersal of the seeds
mainData.point2: Some flowers grow in clusters while others grow singly. All flowers, however, have a protected ovary to contain the seeds and stamens to produce pollen.Flowers often have showy petals and produce sweet nectar to attract insects.
mainData.point3: After the flower opens, the sepals can often be seen behind the petals. The sepals protect and sometimes support the corolla (which refers to a group of petals). The petals send signals to insects that there is nectar in the flower.
mainData.point4: Nectar is secreted at the base of the petals on the inside of the flower. The nectar is used to lure insects to the flower and the insects get a dusting of pollen as they crawl into the flower to reach for the nectar. Then the insects fly off to other flowers, taking the pollen from the first flower with them.
mainData.point5: Insects carry the pollen from flower to flower to pollinate the flowers which eventually results in fertilisation of the reproductive cells between male and female flowers

mainData.point1: The flower holds the reproductive parts-stamen (male reproductive part) and pistil (female reproductive part). The stamen produces pollen grains (male reproductive cells). The pistil is in the centre of the flower. The unfertilised seeds (also known as ovules) are located at the bottom of the pistil.
mainData.point2: The pistil makes up the female reproductive part of a flower Seeds are produced here. A flower may have one or more pistils.The parts of a pistil include the:
mainData.point3: Stigma - a small, sticky pad where the pollen grains stick to a tube where the pollen grains grow down towards the ovary.
mainData.point4: Style - a tube where the pollen grains grow down towards the ovary.
mainData.point5: Ovary - contains the embryo seeds (or ovules) which grow into seeds once fertilised.
mainData.point6: Generally the will of the ovary protects the developing seeds. When the seeds are mature, they are often found in some sort of encasement. The encasement could be o pod, a fruit or a berry. These seeds are usually scattered far away from the parent plant by the various forms of seed dispersal.
mainData.point7: Stamen The stamen is the male reproductive organ of a flower It is made up of two parts
mainData.point8: Filament - a slender stem that supports the anther
mainData.point9: Anther - contains pollen a where pollen grains are formed, it splits to release the pollen during pollination
mainData.point10: The anthers open when the pollen is mature, releasing a fine, powdery dust. Some types of pollen are only ripe for few days while some lost much longer. We often think of pollen as yellow powder, but it can be white, orange, brown, purple or black, and it comes in many different shapes and sizes. These pollen grains are easily picked up by an insect or a bird. A flower may receive pollen from many different kinds of plants. However, only pollen grains from the same kind of plant will begin to grow.

mainData.point1: Pollination is the transfer of pollen from anther of a flower to the stigma of the same flower or of another flower. There one few flowers that con self pollinate. Pollination has to happen before fertilisation can take place.
mainData.point2: Many plants are pollinated by animals. Plants may attract pollinators by having colourful flowers, fragrances and sugary nectar.
mainData.point3: As the pollinators climb around flower searching for and drinking the nectar, their bodies are covered with pollen As a pollinator moves from one flower to the next, pollen falls from the pollinators body as it moves, thus pollination the flowers. Bees, ladybirds, moths, butterflies, birds, bots, giraffes and beetles are some animals that pollinate plants. We can also pollinate plants as we brush against flowers and inadvertently collect and transfer pollen
mainData.point4: In some plants, pollen falls from the anther to the stigma on the same flower, thus eliminating the need for a pollinator. This process is called self-pollination. Self-pollination is beneficial for plants that are isolated from their own kind. Self-pollination is usually undesirable, because it reduces the chances of getting new combinations of genes
mainData.point5: In wind pollination, pollen is distributed by wind among the flowers. These species of plants do not develop scented flowers nor do they produce nectar. Male and female reproductive organs are generally found in separate flowers, the male flowers having a number of long filaments terminating in exposed stamens, and the female flowers having long, feather-like stigma. Pollen from wind pollinated flowers tends to be smaller and lighter than pollen from insect pollinated flowers. These pollen have very low nutritional value to insects

mainData.point1: Fertilisation is the fusion of sperm and egg. This takes place in the ovule. For fertilisation to take place, pollen of the right type must join up with the ovules. The pollen that falls on the stigma germinates and the pollen tube grows out and grows through the style toward the ovule.The ovules contain the DNA of the female parent plant, but cannot develop into complete seeds until they have had the DNA of the male parent plant  added.
mainData.point2: Fruits and seeds result from sexual reproduction in flowering plants. The is an ovary that has developed and matured A fruit usually contains seeds.Fruits are adaptations for dispersing seeds while seeds function in the disperse and propagation of plants. Some fruits are fleshy with parts that are edible Some fruits are dry while others are heavy and are designed to be dispersed by falling and rolling away from the parent plant. Some have wings or fluffy take to enable them to be carried away by the wind to be dispersed.
mainData.point3: The DNA is contained in chromosomes and when the ovules or stamens on being made, the DNA of the plant divides in half, and each parent puts o set its own chromosomes into its half of the reproductive element (the the female parent and the pollen for the male parent) ovules do When the ovules are fertilised, the two sets of chromosomes join together to make the double set which a new plant needs The fact that the same genes are passed on to each succeeding generation what makes the new plant similar to its parents; for example, daisies produce daisies in the next generation and do not have the DNA to produce After fertilization, the ovule becomes a seed and the ovary becomes a fruit.
mainData.point4: There are basically two types of fruits Fleshy fruits and Dry fruits
mainData.point5: Seeds develop from the ovules in the female plant, after they have been fertilised by the pollen from the male parent plant Seeds are not visible unless the more mature and ripe. Unripe seeds are soft, White or green, and enclosed in a hard green fleshy fruit (pod). When seeds are ripe and mature, they change colour
mainData.point6: The structure of a seed consists of:
mainData.point7: Cotyledons - Food storage organs that function as first seed leaves
mainData.point11: Radicle - Stem tip developing into a root
mainData.point12: A seed protects and nourishes the embryo in it Seeds may differ in appearance bond Structures. However, all seeds contain a plant embryo and store food in a protective coot. Although it takes more energy for a plant to produce seeds than spores, seeds have on advantage over spores in their ability to remain dormant.

mainData.point1: Seed dispersal is the scattering of offspring away from each other and from the parent plant.
mainData.point2: There are two main advantages of seed dispersal, which are, Improved chances of success by reducing competition and overcrowding and enables colonisation of new suitable habitats increased chance of species survival.
mainData.point3: Fruits which are dispersed by water have fruits and seeds which ore usually fibrous and con foot on water. For example, buoyant fruits, eg sedge and coconut and buoyant seeds, e.g. water lily pong pong, nipah and lotus.
mainData.point4: Seed dispersed by animal are sticky or have little hooks on them. These burrs stick to the fur of passing animals and are carried away to grow in new place, eg burdock, love grass and mimosa
mainData.point5: Seed dispersal by splitting or explosive mechanism There are two types of splitting action for fruits which are dispersed in this manner. For example explosive oration, eg baham and rubber and fruits which split open but without an explosive action eg. African tulip and kapok.
mainData.point6: Seed dispersal by wind Fruits which are dispersed by wind have characteristics like wing-like structure, eg. angsana, shorea, dandelion and sycamore, lightweight seeds which enable them to be transported by the wind, e.g orchid and grass, fine hairs to enable them to float in air, e.g lalang
mainData.point7: Fleshy and juicy fruits which act as a food source The fruits are fragrant, sweet and attractively coloured. The seeds pass through the animal digestive tracts or are carried together with the fruit to a new location. Eg, tomato, rambutan, guava, durian, apple and mango. Other plants produce nuts - seeds with hard tells. These seeds roll and bounce, and are gathered by small animals like squirrels

mainData.point1: Seeds must be placed in proper environmental conditions-optimal moisture, proper temperature, and ample oxygen for them to germinate. Only when these conditions are met would seed germination time place.
mainData.point2: Deploying of germination often assures the survival of the plant. For example, if the seeds that mature in autumn were to sprout immediately, the young plants could be killed by cold weather. If all of a plant's seeds were to sprout at once and all of the new seeds died before producing seeds, the species could become extinct.
mainData.point3: However, for some species of plants, many of their seeds will not germinate even when exposed to conditions ideal for germination. Such seeds exhibit dormancy. In order to germinate and break dormancy, a seed has to absorb quite a bit of water. In nature, seeds absorb this water from the soil.
mainData.point4: Environmental factors such as water, Oxygen, and temperature trigger seed germination. Most seeds are very dry and must absorb water to germinat. Water softens the seed coat and activates enzymes that convert starch in the cotyledon or endosperm Into simple sugars, which provide energy for the embryo to grow.
mainData.point5: The first visible sign of seed germination is the emergence of the radicle root) soon after the radicle breaks the seed coat, the shoot begins to grow.The embryonic leaves unfold. synthesise chlorophyll and begin to carry out photosynthesis. After their stored nutrients are used up, the shrunken cotyledons fall off
mainData.point6: As the embryo begins to grow, the softened seed coat cracks open, ennobling the oxygen needed for cellular respiration to reach the embryo. Seeds will only germinate if the temperature is within a certain range. Some seeds germinate only after being exposed to extreme conditions, after freezing or passing through a digestive system that breaks down the seed coats

mainData.point1: Survival is a daily challenge for all living things.Every living organism struggles to survive. But individual survival is not enough to ensure the continuity of a particular species. As all Living things continually face threats to their survival and life cycle, reproduction in species must occur to ensure continuity of their own kind. Some species give birth to their young one at a time while others give birth to many at a time. For example, a cow gives birth to one calf at a time while a frog lays many eggs at one time.

There are a few ways in which organisms can reproduce. In uncertain and dangerous environments, organisms will produce many offspring. The more offspring there are, the higher the chances of survival of their species. The life expectancy of these offspring is short as most of these offspring will die before they become adults or before they are ready to reproduce. The parents do not look after their young. The young mature rapidly and reproduce at an early age. They are thus able to reproduce so many offspring as quickly as possible.Animals with many offspring may devote fewer resources to each individual offspring, for these types of animals it is common for a large number of offspring to die soon after birth, but there are sufficient numbers that survive to maintain the population of their species.
mainData.point2: In a stable environment, with a predictable supply of resources and few dangers, organisms produce few offspring. These offspring are cared for by their parents. They are well-developed and tend to live longer. They mature slowly and reproduce at a late age.

mainData.point1: Fertilisation is the union of sex cells (sperm and egg) to form a new organism, a zygote (fertilised ovum), which develops into an embryo.Depending on the species of the animal, fertilisation can occur within the body of the female in internal fertilisation or outside the body of the animal in external fertilisation.
mainData.point2: The process of internal fertilisation begins when the male deposits its sperm directly into the female's body. In most mammals and some reptiles, the embryo develops inside the female's body after fertilisation.Most land animals like insects, some reptiles and mammals reproduce by internal fertilisation. However, in birds and most other reptiles, the embryo develops outside the female's body. The female usually lays an egg where the embryo develops within. The egg is protected by a shell that contains material which nourishes the growing embryo and enables it to develop fully.
mainData.point3: During external fertilisation, the male and female reproductive cells unite outside the female's body. This process usually takes place in the water. The male releases its sperms into the water at about the same time that the female release her eggs. Some of the sperms will come into contact with some of the eggs and fertilise them. Most of the aquatic invertebrates and some vertebrates, including the majority of fish and amphibians, reproduce by external fertilisation. The eggs of most fish are fertilised externally.

mainData.point1: Reproduction is a fundamental feature of all life. It is a biological process bu which new individual organisms are produced. The reproductive process always includes the transfer of hereditary materials from the parent to its offspring so that they too can reproduce. There are two basic types of reproduction--asexual reproduction and sexual reproduction
mainData.point2: Asexual reproduction is the production of new individuals without the union of sex cells sperm and egg). The continuity of life is assured by mitosis. A cell replicates its DNA and becomes two new daughter cells, each having identical characteristics and carrying on the same life functions as the parent cell.Asexual reproduction is common among simple organisms such as amoeba and single-celled organisms However, it is not limited to single celled organisms. Most plants have the ability to reproduce asexually. Examples of asexual reproduction in plants and single-celled organisms include budding and binary fission respectively
mainData.point3: sexual reproduction is the production of offspring through the union of male (sperm) and female (egg) sex cells. In this process, two individuals are required - a male and a female.

mainData.point1: Male reproductive system The male reproductive system contains two main parts the penis and the testes. In a male reproductive system, there are two egg-shaped testes The testes produce the sperm The testes lie between the testes between the thighs in a pair of pouch-like bogs called Scrotum or scrotal sac forts of the reproductive parts of the male reproductive system The scrotum or scrotal sacs, which are found outside the body. Therefore, they have a lower temperature than that of the body. This is necessary for the sperms to develop properly. Sperms are only able to develop at temperature that is lower than that of its body temperature.The penis consists of tissues that have numerous spaces which can be filled with blood.
mainData.point2: The female reproductive system consists of the ovary the oviduct, the uterus, the cervix and the vagina.The ovary produces eggs. When the eggs are mature, they are released from the ovaries. The uterus, also known as the womb, is where the foetus develops during pregnancy. The ovaries are connected to the uterus via the oviduct or fallopian tubes, At certain intervals, the ovaries release an ovum, which passes through the fallopian tube into the uterus, where the egg is usually fertilised in the oviduct. The cervix is located at the lower end of the uterus. During birth, it enlarges to allow the foetus to pass through the vagina.

mainData.point1: Life for an offspring begins when the sperm cell reaches the egg cell during the process of fertilisation. Egg cells mature in the ovary and ore then released into the abdominal cavity called the oviduct. It is within the oviduct that fertilisation takes place. Some mammals, such as dogs, cats and rabbits release several eggs at once, resulting in multiple births Others such as horses, cows and elephants.

Gestation is the period of time during which the foetus develop inside the female, During this time, the foetus receives all of its nutrition and oxygenated blood from the mother filtered through the placenta, which is attached to the foetus abdomen via on umbilical cord.
mainData.point2: Gestation, also known as pregnancy in humans is divided into three periods known as trimesters. Each trimester is 3 months long During these periods, the drain of nutrients can be quite taxing on the mother, who is required to ingest significantly higher levels of calories. In addition, certain vitamins and other nutrients are required in greater quantities than normal often requiring higher consumption of food.The length of gestation for humans range between 37 and 42 weeks.The length of gestation varies greatly from species to species. For dog, their gestation period is nine weeks regardless of breed, 5660 weeks in giraffes and 16 days in hamsters

mainData.point1: When gestation is completed, the foetus that is growing in the mother's womb born alive, having moved through the birth canal. The foetus is ready to breathe air without the umbilical cord for the first time and receive food through its digestive system. The umbilical cord connecting the foetus to the placenta will be cut completely, freeing the newborn from the mother. The placenta will then be expelled by the womb, so that the womb can heal and prepare for another pregnancy. In animals, the umbilical cord is bitten off and eaten by the mother to nourish her and to recycle the proteins.
mainData.point2: Some mammals such as mice, cats and rabbits are born blind and helpless. Mammals with longer gestation periods, such as horses, elephants and cattle are able to stand, walk and even run almost immediately after birth.

mainData.point1: Heredity is the genetic transmission of characteristic traits from the parent offspring by means of genes in the chromosomes of the cells. This transmission of characteristics takes place either through sexual or asexual reproduction.
mainData.point2: Genes determine a person's appearance-height hair colour, skin colour and eye colour. Mental abilities and natural talents are also affected by heredity as is the susceptibility to acquire certain diseases. The gene is defined as the unit of inheritance. Chemically speaking, each gene is the blueprint for a specific type of protein in the body. Proteins are important because they perform many functions in the cells and the human body.
mainData.point3: Proteins are made of smaller units called amino acids.There are twenty types of amino acids the human body. Different combinations and numbers of these amino acids make different types of proteins. That means one protein may only have four amino acids while another has twenty; two proteins may both have twenty amino acids but are in a different order in each protein. Each amino acid is made up of three nucleotide bases found in DNA, also known as deoxyribonucleic acid. Each DNA molecule consists of two parallel strands twisted around each other to form a double helix. A helix is a coiled structure like a corkscrew or spring. A molecule of DNA is wrapped around proteins to form a single chromatin thread. During cell division, chromatin threads coil tightly into structures called chromosomes inside the cell nucleus.
mainData.point4: Chromosomes, genes and DNA A gene is a small segment of DNA that contains information that is used to make a single protein. Each protein is responsible for determining a particular characteristic of an organism. Coiled DNA molecules are called chromatin threads or chromosomes, which are found inside the nucleus of a cell. Within the DNA molecule, genes exist that specify a certain, single characteristic For example, there is a gene for height, a gene for weight, and a gene for eye colour, etc.
mainData.point5: Variations of the gene relating to the same trait are called alleles. Individuals carry two genes for each trait, one from the mother's egg and one from the father's sperm. When an individual reproduces, the two genes split up and end up in separate reproductive cells. One of these two genes is dominant over the other. The dominant allele will mask the other, called the recessive allele. For example, if the father gives a tall allele of the height gene, and the other gives a short allele, the offspring will be tall. This is because tall is dominant and short is recessive.
mainData.point6: Human beings have cells with 46 chromosomes - 2 sex chromosomes (XX or XY) and 22 poirs of non-sex chromosomes. In the process of reproductive cell division, by which ova and sperms are produced, the chromosomes are divided so that each mature reproductive cell contains half (23) of the original number of chromosomes, or one chromosome of each pair. Thus, when the ovum and the sperm fuse on fertilisation, the fertilised egg receives one set of chromosomes from each parent and the original number of chromosomes (46) is restored.
mainData.point7: The characteristics that an organism inherits from its parents are called traits:
mainData.point8: Traits are genetically determined. In humans, traits include things such as the colour of a person's hair, skin and eyes, the blood group, the shape of nose and lips, and the tendency to be short-sighted or to become bald. Certain human traits can be modified by the influence of the environment, while others cannot:
mainData.point9: Blood type is an inherited trait that will not change, whereas the tendency to be tall or short con be modified by what you eat, how fast you grow, illnesses and other factors
mainData.point10: Sometimes, it is possible to show a trait which neither of the parents exhibits This means that these genes are passed on from someone else in your family. It could be your grandparents for example, who have that trait.
mainData.point11: Sometimes such traits can even come from great-grandparents. This is because of recessive genes. Recessive genes are genes whose trait is not displayed or expressed. The dominant gene is the gene whose trait is displayed or expressed over the unexpressed or recessive gene.

mainData.point1: Water is unique as it is the only natural substance that is found in all three states at room temperature solid liquid and gas The Earth's water is constant interacting, changing and moving
mainData.point2: Water can change from one state to another when its temperature changes. The temperature of water will increase or decrease until it reaches the point where the change takes place. It will then stay at that temperature until that change is completed

mainData.point1: The states of water are solid, liquid and gas. Water exists in the liquid state at room temperature. If we cool it down, it changes into ice. If we heat it, it changes into steam.
mainData.point2: When heat is applied to ice, its change in state typically goes from solid to liquid to gas. When water vapour is cooled, its change in state typically goes from gas to liquid to solid

mainData.point1: When water reaches the temperature at which a change in state occurs, the temperature will remain the same until all the energy is used to change its state
mainData.point2: When ice is heated, its temperature rises until it reaches its melting point (0°C).Then the ice will stay at that temperature until all the ice has melted. Heat energy is used to melt the ice and not to raise the temperature. After the ice has melted, the temperature of the water will continue to rise as more heat is applied. Thus, any additional heat added to the ice will not raise the temperature until all of the ice has melted. The additional energy merely supplies enough energy to cause the ice to melt.
mainData.point3: When water is heated, its temperature rises until it reaches its boiling point (100°C). The temperature will then remain at that point until all of the liquid is boiled away into steam. The temperature of the steam can then be increased.

mainData.point1: Likewise, when water vapour is cooled, its temperature will drop until it reaches the condensation point.
mainData.point2: Any additional cooling or heat loss will not lower the temperature until all of the gas has condensed into liquid. The temperature of water will continue to drop as more cooling is applied. Once water reaches the freezing point (0°C), the temperature will remain at that point until all of the liquid has solidified and the temperature of ice can then continue to decrease.
mainData.point3: Evaporation is a process where liquid changes into gas. Unlike boiling which occurs at a fixed boiling point of the substance, evaporation takes place at any temperature. This occurs when the atoms or molecules in a sufficient energy to enter the gaseous state. This process is the opposite of condensation.
mainData.point4: However, evaporation proceeds more quickly at a higher temperature. Since only a small proportion of the molecules are located near the surface and are moving in the proper direction to escape at any given instant, the rate of evaporation is limited. Also, as the faster-moving molecules escape, the remaining molecules have lower average kinetic energy, and the temperature of the liquid thus decreases. This phenomenon is called evaporative cooling.
mainData.point5: The rate of evaporation is dependent on the following factors:

mainData.point1: It is a natural cycle. The water cycle is also called the hydrologic cycle. It is the continuous movement of water from the Earth's surface into the air and back to the Earth's surface again. Water undergoes several changes in state through different processes in the water cycle.
mainData.point2: Water can be found in all three states during the water cycle:
mainData.point6: The heat from the Sun is the driving force for the water cycle.
mainData.point7: The water cycle ensures the continuous movement of water around the Earth. It ensures that the amount of water on the Earth remains the same over the years.

mainData.point1: Water is essential to all living things. Plants derive some of their nutrients from minerals in the soil. These minerals have to be dissolved in water in order to be absorbed by the plants. Water is taken into the human body by consuming plants, meat and beverages.
mainData.point2: Humans can go for a month without eating but will die in three to five days without water because our bodies are made up of about 70 per cent water. The body uses water to maintain its temperature, breathe, digest food and lubricate moving joints.
mainData.point3: A wide variety of animal life, in or around freshwater ecosystems, like aquatic birds, amphibians, mammals and a wide variety of fish depend on water for survival.
mainData.point4: Some of the most important uses of water are at our homes. It is used for indoor and outdoor purposes. All the things you do at home drinking, preparing food, bathing, washing clothes and dishes, brushing your teeth, watering the yard and garden and even washing the dog make use of water.
mainData.point5: Use of water in commercial places is important because without it, we would not have any restaurants pizza houses, coffee shops, food centres and other eateries. Along with the eateries, water is commercially supplied to motels, offices, prisons military Institutions and fish hatcheries
mainData.point6: The industries that produce metals, wood and paper products, chemicals, gasoline, oils and probably every manufactured product use water during some parts of the production process.
mainData.point7: Throughout the world, irrigation (water for agriculture or growing crops) is probably the most important use of water. Almost 60 per cent of all the world's freshwater withdrawals go towards irrigation uses. Large-scale farming will not be able to provide food for the world's large population without the irrigation of crop fields by water from rivers, lakes, reservoirs and wells. Without irrigation, crops could never grow.
mainData.point8: Water is needed to raise livestock such as cows, chickens, horses and rabbits. Here, water is needed for watering, feeding, dairy operations and other forms of  needs. This includes water for raising cows, chickens, horses, rabbits, fish and other animals. Water is also used in the production of meat, poultry eggs and milk
mainData.point9: Production of electrical power results in one of the largest uses of water worldwide. Water for thermoelectric power is used in generating electricity with steam driven turbine generators.
mainData.point10: Like other industries, mining corporations need water to make bare rocks give up valuable minerals. Water is used for the extraction of minerals that may be in the form of solids such as coal, iron, sand and gravel: liquids such as crude petroleum and gases such as natural gas. Water is needed to carry out activities such as quarrying, milling (crushing, screening, washing and flotation of mined materials, re-injecting extracted water for secondary oil recovery and other operations associated with mining activities.
mainData.point11: Hydroelectric energy is produced by the force of falling water. The capacity to produce this energy is dependent on both the available flow and the height from which the water falls. As water builds up behind a high dam, it accumulates potential energy.
mainData.point12: The gained potential energy is transformed into mechanical energy when the water rushes down the sluice and strikes the rotary blades of the turbine.

mainData.point1: A force is a push or a pull. It is an action that has an effect on an object. It can also be a combination of both pushes and pulls. In Science, an object that is being pushed or pulled is called a body.
mainData.point2: A force is described as an action on a body/ We may also say that the force is applied to the body. Forces cannot be seen but their effects can be seen and felt.
mainData.point3: A force gives an object the energy to start moving, stop moving or change its direction of motion. All motion takes place under the influence of some forces.
mainData.point4: Thus, a force can also be defined as the influence that changes the speed and direction of a stationary or a moving body. A force can change the state of rest or uniform motion of a body.
mainData.point5: A force can either change the size and shape of an object, such as a spring, or change the speed or direction of an object.
mainData.point6: A force can give energy to an object causing the object to start moving, stop moving, or change its motion.

mainData.point1: Forces occur in pairs and can either be balanced or unbalanced.
mainData.point2: Unlike balanced forces, unbalanced forces always cause a change in the direction of motion. They are not equal and are unbalanced. When two unbalanced forces are exerted in opposite directions, their combined force is equal to the difference between the two forces and is exerted in the direction of the larger force.
mainData.point3: Balanced forces do not cause a change in motion. They are equal in strength and opposite in direction.

mainData.point1: A force cannot be seen but its effects can be seen or felt.
mainData.point2: There are two ways we can experience the effects of a force:
mainData.point4: indirect contact forces/forces resulting from action-at-a-distance
mainData.point5: Contact forces ore types of forces in which the two Interacting objects ore physically in contact each other.
mainData.point6: Some examples of contact forces are:
mainData.point9: when a stationary ball is being kicked, it starts to roll
mainData.point10: when a hand presses on a ball of plasticine, the shape of the plasticine is being changed
mainData.point11: Indirect contact forces are types of forces in which the two interacting objects are not in physical contact with each other, out are able to exert a push or a pull despite a physical separation. Some examples of indirect forces are gravitational force, magnetic force and electric force.
mainData.point12: Sometimes two forces act on an object. The sum of these forces is called the net force. If the net forces are balanced, there is no change in the motion of the object, as the two forces are equal in size and their direction of motion are opposite each other. If the forces are unbalanced, then the forves change the motion or speed of the object

mainData.point1: We can draw diagrams to describe a force. In doing so, we can provide some details of a force. You can show a force on a drawing by using a arrow
mainData.point2: We use arrows to show whether a force is a push or a  pull
mainData.point3: We use arrows to show the size of a force. A longer arrow indicates a bigger force while a shorter arrow indicates a smaller force
mainData.point4: We use arrows to show where the body is being pushed or pulled. This is described as the position of the applied force.
mainData.point5: We can also use arrows to show the direction of the applied force.

mainData.point1: Gravity is the reason why things fall towards the centre of the Earth.
mainData.point2: Here are some examples to show the presence of gravity:
mainData.point3: People who parachute out of planes fall to the ground
mainData.point4: Things fall off tables onto the floor
mainData.point5: Balls thrown into the air fall back to the ground

mainData.point1: When we talk about the weight of an object, everyone knows that we are talking about how heavy or light the object is. For example, we can make a statement "The weight of a car is 1500 kilograms".
mainData.point2: In Science, we use two important words and they are weight and mass. However, these two words do not have the same meaning.
mainData.point3: Weight is the gravitational force pulling the body towards the centre of the Earth. We use springs to measure weight. When you weigh something on the spring scale, give the object a slight pull down and observe the increase in the reading
mainData.point4: Mass is the amount of matter in a body Other words for matter are materials and substances. We usually divide matter into three groups-solids liquids and gases

mainData.point1: Friction is a force that resists any movement of one surface over another.
mainData.point2: We can experience friction in some everyday events like rubbing our hands together, sliding heavy loads across surfaces and in car and bicycle tyres. When you rub your hands together, they get warm. As one hand slides over the other, there is friction and this creates heat.
mainData.point3: Friction results when one surface slides over another and it is caused by the roughness of the surfaces. Even surfaces that seem smooth can look quite different under a microscope
mainData.point4: If you try to push or pull a heavy box across the floor, you will find it hard to get started. Friction between the bottom surface of the box and the floor makes it hard to move the box.
mainData.point5: However, friction causes certain effects in machines.
mainData.point6: Friction between two surfaces wastes energy, as surfaces sliding over each other results in more energy needed to start the machine and keep it moving
mainData.point7: Friction causes two surfaces that are in contact with each other to get hot
mainData.point8: Friction causes wear and tear between surfaces that are in contact with each other for a while.
mainData.point11: Lubrication such as oil to keep the surfaces apart
mainData.point12: Rollers or ball bearings between two sliding surfaces
mainData.point13: There are times when we need friction to make things work. For example, tyres on cars and bicycles must grip the road so that the car will not skid, especially when roads are wet and slippery.

mainData.point1: Magnetism is the attractive or repulsive force that acts between magnetic materials such as iron, steel, cobalt and nickel. It is a force that acts at a distance s caused by a magnetic field.
mainData.point2: he magnetic field in a bar magnet has two definite poles. Scientists in the earlier periods referred to these poles as the North and South poles.
mainData.point3: The lines of magnetic flux flow from one end of the magnetic object to the other. By convention, we call one end of a magnetic object the N or  North- seeking pole and the other, the S or South-seeking pole, as related to the Earth's north and south magnetic poles
mainData.point4: The magnetic flux is defined as moving from N to 5. A magnetic force is developed between two bar magnets. When the poles are alike, N-N or SS, the magnetic force that develops between them is a repelling force. When the poles are opposite; N-S or S-N, the magnetic force that develops between them is an attracting force.
mainData.point5: Materials that are attracted by a magnet, such as iron, steel, nickel, and cobalt have the ability to become magnetised. These are called magnetic materials. These objects experience a magnetic force when placed in the presence of a magnet. This magnetic force pulls the objects to the magnet.

mainData.point1: When an object is acted upon by a force, it can be compressed, stretched or bent. If the force is removed and the object returns to its original shape, it is said to be elastic.
mainData.point2: elasticity is the property of an object or material which causes it to be restored to its original shape after distortion. An object is said to be more elastic if it restores itself more precisely to its original shape after distortion.
mainData.point3: Solids that do not return to their original shape once they have been distorted are categorised as non-elastic.

mainData.point1: Man depends on his environment for natural resources
mainData.point2: Natural resources are resources that occur naturally the Earth Examples air, forests, fossil fuels, land, water, metals and minerals
mainData.point3: Natural resources are important for Man to obtain energy, food and materials.
mainData.point4: Man's interactions with his environment have both positive and negative effects

mainData.concepts: Negative impact of Man's activities on his environment
mainData.point1: Fossil fuels such coal, oil and gas used energy source vehicles factories. They are obtained from under the They were formed remains of living things millions of years ago. Once they are depleted, they cannot be replaced
mainData.point2: Metals and minerals are obtained from the ground to make things such as machines, utensils and jewellery. Once they how been depleted, they cannot be replaced
mainData.point3: Deforestation is the clearing of large areas of forested land by cutting and burning down trees
mainData.point4: Deforestation is carried out to provide land for people to use for farming or building on this is why farming hos both positive and negative effects on the environment), allow people to dig up fuels and minerals from the ground and wood which can be used to make paper and furniture
mainData.point5: Pollution is caused by releasing pollutants into the environment. A pollutant is any substance that makes the environment dirty or harmful to live in.
mainData.point6: Pollution can affect the land, air and water bodies such as seas.
mainData.point7: Pollution can be caused by litter, chemicals, CFCs, untreated human waste, smoke, haze and acid rain
mainData.point8: Certain gases in the Earth's atmosphere, such as carbon dioxide, trap heat from the Sun and makes the Earth warm. This warming effect is known as the greenhouse effect, which keeps the Earth from freezing.
mainData.point9: Greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide are given off as a result of deforestation and the burning of fossil fuels.
mainData.point10: However, too many greenhouse gases in the atmosphere will lead to the surface of our Earth becoming much warmer as more heat is trapped. This is called global warming.
mainData.point11: The ice around the poles may melt as a result of global warming. The sea level would then rise and places near the sea would be completely flooded

mainData.concepts: Positive impact of Man's activities on his environment
mainData.point1: Man is responsible for protecting his environment. He needs to carry out actions that have a positive impact on his environment. Some of the ways in which this can be done are conservation of natural resources and reforestation.
mainData.point2: We can conserve natural resources by practising the 3Rs - reducing, reusing and recycling
mainData.point3: We need to take measures to reduce land, water and air pollution. Some ways to do this are by disposing of rubbish properly, keeping the environment clean and travelling by public transport instead of by car.
mainData.point4: We need to protect wildlife by conserving natural habitats and preventing overfishing.
mainData.point5: Reforestation should be carried out to reduce the negative effects of deforestation.
mainData.point6: Reforestation involves planting seeds and young plants in forests where trees have been cut down. This will help to restore the forests and the wildlife that lives there.
mainData.point7: Planting new trees will also help reduce the amount of carbon dioxide and global warming

mainData.concepts: What is the plant tranport system?
mainData.point1: The food made by leaves is transported to the other parts of a plant such as the roots, the stem, the flowers and the fruits.
mainData.point2: Water and minerals absorbed by the roots are also transported to the other parts of the plant.
mainData.point3: The plant transport system transports these substances to various parts of the plants.
mainData.point4: The transport system is made up of two types of tubes: The water-carrying tubes and the food-carrying tubes
mainData.point5: THe water carrying tube, also know as xylem, runs from the roots to the other parts of the plant.
mainData.point6: The xylem transport water and minerals and supports the plant.
mainData.point7: The food-carrying tubes, also know as phloem, runs from the leaves to the other parts of the plants.

mainData.concepts: How does the plant transport system work?
mainData.point1: The water-carrying tubes and food-carrying tubes function concurrently.
mainData.point2: water-carrying tubes transport water and minerals from the roots, up the stem to the other parts of the plant.
mainData.point3: Food-carrying tubes transport food(sugar) made in the leaves to different parts of the plants. Plants use this sugar to carry out life processes.
mainData.point4: When a stalk of celery is placed in coloured water for some time, the water-carrying tubes transport the coloured water up the stem.

mainData.concepts: What are the components of air?
mainData.point1: There is a layer of gas that surrounds Earth called the atmosphere.
mainData.point2: Earth's atmosphere is a mixture of gases called air.
mainData.point3: Moving air is know as wind.
mainData.point4: Air is made up of about 78% nitrogen, 21% oxygen, 0.03% carbon dioxide and the rest consists of a variable amount of water vapour and other gases.
mainData.point5: To remember the composition of gas, you can use the acronym CROWNS that stands for the main components of air
mainData.point6: Carbon dioxide, Rare gases(such as argon), Oxygen, Water vapour, Nitrogen, Some other gases(such as carbon monoxide and sulfur dioxide)
mainData.point7: There is a variable amount of water vapour and other gases such as sulfur dioxide and carbon monoxide.

mainData.concepts: What are the components of air? (Oxygen)
mainData.point1: Oxygen is essential to all living things.
mainData.point2: Plants and animals take in oxygen from the air to carry out their life processes.
mainData.point3: Oxygen is needed by living things to break down food and use it to obtain energy. This process is known as respiration.
mainData.point4: Living things that live in water take in oxygen dissolved in water.
mainData.point5: Living things that live underground use the oxygen found in the soil.
mainData.point6: Oxygen is produced when plants make their food by a process call photosynthesis.
mainData.point7: Oxygen is needed for burning. When an object burns, it combines with the oxygen in the air. A continuous supply of oxygen is needed to keep things burning.

mainData.concepts: What are the components of air? (Nitrogen)
mainData.point1: Nitrogen is the most abundant gas in the air.
