mainData.point2: It does not support burning.

mainData.concepts: What are the components of air? (Carbon dioxide)
mainData.point1: Carbon dioxide is given off when living thingd carry out their life processes.
mainData.point2: Carbon dioxide is also produced when things burh or decay.
mainData.point3: Plants use carbon dioxide to make their food during photosynthesis.
mainData.point4: This exchange of gases happens continuously to maintain a healthy balance of oxygen and carbon dioxide in the air.

mainData.concepts: What are the components of air? (Water vapour)
mainData.point1: The water vapour in the air is an essential link in the water cycle and has a significant effect on the weather. Clouds are formed from water vapour.
mainData.point2: The water vapour returns to Earth as rain, snow or other forms of precipitation.
mainData.point3: The water vapour is produced when water evaporates into air, living things breath out or when things decay.
mainData.point4: The amount of water vapour in the air varies from place to place. Places near the ocean have more water vapour in the air.

mainData.concepts: What are the components of air? (Rare gases)
mainData.point1: The rare or nobel gases present in the air are argon, helium, neon, krypton and xenon.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: What are the main differences between breathing and repiration.
mainData.point1: Breathing is taking in and giving out air.
mainData.point2: Respiration is the reaction in the cells when oxygen and nutrients are used to produce carbon dioxide and energy.
mainData.point3: Parts of the body involved in breathing: Nose, Mouth, Windpipe, Diaphragm and Lungs.
mainData.point4: The role of oxygen in breathing: Taken is as part of the air breathed in
mainData.point5: Role of carbon dioxide in breathing: Given off as part of the air breathed out.
mainData.point6: Parts of the body involved in Respiration: All living cells of the body
mainData.point7: The role of oxygen in breathing: Used to break down food and release energy
mainData.point8: Role of carbon dioxide in breathing: Produced when food is broken down
mainData.point9: Breathing in is the physical act of taking in air.
mainData.point10: Breathing out is the physical act of giving out air.
mainData.point11: A comparison between the characteristics of air breathed in and out are outlined below
mainData.point12: Breathing in, also know as inhaling, is the process of taking in air for respiration. Inhaled air contains less carbon dioxide (0.03%), more oxygen (20.85%), less water vapour (0.5%) and less heat.
mainData.point13: Breathing out, also know as Exhaling, is the giving out carbon dioxide produced during respiration. Exhaled air contains more carbon dioxide (3.6%), less oxygen (15.3%), more water vapour (6.3%) and more heat.
mainData.point14: Only a fraction of the oxygen inhaled is taken up by the lungs. The composition of water vapour is more in exhaled air compared to inhaled air.

mainData.concepts: What are the functions of the organs in the respiratory system?
mainData.point1: The pathway taken by through the respiratory system is shown.
mainData.point2: Air --> Nose --> Windpipe --> Air Tubes --> Air sacs in lungs
mainData.point3: All the cells in our body require oxygen and we get the oxygen through breathing in the air.
mainData.point4: The human respiratory system consists of the nose, windpipe, air tubes, lungs and air sacs.
mainData.point5: The nose allows air to enter and leave the body. It contains hair and mucus to trap the dirt in the air. The air that passes through is also warmed and moistened.
mainData.point6: The windpipe transfers the air from the nose to the ait tubes.
mainData.point7: Windpipe branches into two smaller air tubes.The Air Tubes transport the air to the lungs.
mainData.point8: The lungs contain air sacs. It allows exchange of gases in the air sacs. It pick up oxygen from inhaled air. It passes the carbon dioxide into the exhaled air.
mainData.point9: The air sacs have a rich supply of blood vessels. This increases the surface area for exchange of gases. Air sacs absorb oxygen. The oxygen passes through the walls of the sacs into the blood vessels. Carbon dioxide passes from the blood vessels into the air sacs.
mainData.point10: The diaphragm is a dome-shaped sheet of muscle that separates the chest cavity from the abdomen. It is the most important muscle use for breathing.

mainData.concepts: How do organs in the respiratory system work together? (Breathing In)
mainData.point1: The ribs move out and upwards.
mainData.point2: The diagram moved downwards.
mainData.point4: Air rushes into the body through the nose and the mouth.
mainData.point5: Air is cleaned, warmed and moistened in the nose.
mainData.point6: Air moves down the windpipe and sir tubes into the lungs.
mainData.point7: The air tubes branch further and end in balloon-like air sacs that have a rich supply of blood vessels.
mainData.point8: When inhaling, the chest cavity enlarges, reducing the pressure out side the lungs. To equalise the pressure, air enters the lungs,

mainData.concepts: How do organs in the respiratory system work together? (In the lungs)
mainData.point1: Oxygen from the air breathed in passes through the walls of the air sacs into the blood vessels.
mainData.point2: Blood carries oxygen to all parts of the body.
mainData.point3: Carbon dioxide passes from the blood vessels into the air sacs.

mainData.concepts: How do organs in the respiratory system work together? (Breathing Out)
mainData.point1: The ribs move in and downwards.
mainData.point2: The diaphragm moved upwards.
mainData.point4: Air is forced out of the lungs by the chest muscles.

mainData.concepts: How do animals and plants exchange gases with their surroundings?
mainData.point1: The respiratory system is responsible for the exchange fo gases of living with their surroundings.
mainData.point2: DIfferent organisms have different parts that make up their respiratory system. The table below summarises how living things exchange with their surroundings.
mainData.point3: Insects and arachnids have openings that lead to tubes which carry oxygen to their internal organs.
mainData.point4: Fish take in oxygen through their gills. Water contained dissolved oxygen enters the mouth of the fish. It washes over the gills, and the oxygen enters the blood in the gills.As water flows out from under the gill covers, carbon dioxide from the blood is carried away.
mainData.point5: Birds has lungs, and they take in air through their nostrils.
mainData.point6: Mammals have lungs, and they take in air through their nostrils. Some mammals such as whales and dolphins also have lungs but they breathe through blowholes on tap of their heads.
mainData.point7: Amphibians use lungs and skin to breathe. Some amphibians such as salamander take in oxygen through their gills. Frogs can breathe through their moist skin. When they are underwater, they sue moist skin to breathe instead of their lungs.
mainData.point8: Plants have tiny openings, mostly found on the underside of the leaf, called stomata. They sue their stomata for their gaseous exchange. During respiration through the day, plants take in oxygen and produce carbon dioxide. Stomata are commonly found on the underside of leaves, away from direct sunlight to prevent water from evaporating.

mainData.point1: The circulatory system is made up of the heart, blood vessels and blood.
mainData.point2: The heart is a four-chambered muscular organ that pumps blood around the body.
mainData.point3: Blood vessels are a network of tubes which carry blood around the body.
mainData.point4: Blood is a liquid which is the medium of transport in the body.
mainData.point5: The human circulatory system transport oxygen, food and water to all parts of our body. We need oxygen, food and water to stay alive.
mainData.point6: The circulatory system circulates blood in two parts:
mainData.point7: Blood is pumped from the heart to all cells in the body before returning to the heart.
mainData.point8: Blood from all parts of the body is pumped from the heart to the lungs and then back to the heart,

mainData.concepts: What are the parts of the circulatory system? (Heart)
mainData.point1: The heart is a muscular organ situated near the middle part of our chest. It is slightly tilted to the left side of the body and is protected by the ribcage.
mainData.point2: It is a vital organ that pumps blood all the time, to all parts of our body.
mainData.point3: The heart is made of special muscles called heart muscles.
mainData.point4: We cannot control the movements of the heart muscles, though we can control other muscles such as those in the arms and legs.
mainData.point5: Each heartbeat is a cycle of contraction and relaxation of the heart muscles.
mainData.point6: The average rate of the heartbeat of a healthy person is about 60 to 70 times per minute.
mainData.point7: The rate of heartbeat changes with age, health and type of activity the person is doing.
mainData.point8: With each heartbeat, a pressure wave passes along the blood vessels, pushing blood through them. This is known as the pulse.
mainData.point9: We take our pulse by pressing out fingers on our wrist or neck, and counting the number of pulses felt per minute.
mainData.point10: The normal pulse rate of a healthy young adult is about 60 to 70 times per minute. This is measured when the person is at rest.
mainData.point11: The faster the heartbeats, the higher the pulse rate.
mainData.point12: When we exercise, our heart rate increases.
mainData.point13: The body requires a greater supply of digested food and oxygen that is carried in the blood to the various parts of the body. The blood also rapidly removes the carbon dioxide produced. Hence, the heart has to pump blood faster around the body.
mainData.point14: The digested food and oxygen is used for respiration in order to release enough energy for the activity that is taking place.

mainData.concepts: What are the parts of the circulatory system? (Blood Vessels)
mainData.point1: Blood vessels are tubes through which blood flows.
mainData.point2: A network of blood vessels connected to the heart to all parts of our body.
mainData.point3: Other blood vessels carry blood from other parts of our body back to the heart.

mainData.concepts: What are the parts of the circulatory system? (Blood)
mainData.point1: Blood transports digested food, oxygen, water, carbon dioxide and other waste materials to different parts of the body.
mainData.point2: Digested food, oxygen and water are transported to the cell of the body while carbon dioxide and other waste materials are transported away from the cells to the organs that get rid of waste materials, such as the lungs, kidney and skin.
mainData.point3: Blood flows through the blood vessels to get to different parts of our body,

mainData.concepts: How do the organs in the circulatory system work together? (Functions of the Blood Circulatory System)
mainData.point1: Transport oxygen, digested food and water to all parts of the body.
mainData.point2: Carry carbon dioxide and waste materials away from different parts of the body to be released.
mainData.point3: The heart pumps oxygen-rich blood to all parts of the body, through the arteries.
mainData.point4: Blood also carries digested food and water from the digestive system to all parts of the body.
mainData.point5: The arteries branch into fine capillaries.
mainData.point6: The digested food, oxygen and water pass through the thin walls of the capillaries into the cells of the body.
mainData.point7: The cells use digested food, oxygen and water to produce energy. In the process, carbon dioxide and other waste materials are also produced.
mainData.point8: Carbon dioxide and waste materials pass from the cells of the body into capillaries.
mainData.point9: The capillaries merge to form veins.
mainData.point10: The veins transport waste materials to the organs that can remove them from the body, such as kidneys.
mainData.point11: Carbon dioxide-rich blood is returned to the heart and sent to the lungs.

mainData.concepts: How do the other organ systems works together with the Circulatory System?
mainData.point1: Body systems cannot work alone. They are interconnected with one another.
mainData.point2: Some organs could be part of several systems.
mainData.point3: The following points shows how the circulatory system is interconnected with the respiratory, digestive and muscular system.
mainData.point4: Circulatory and Respiratory system: It provides oxygen for the organs. Oxygen is carried by red blood cells to all parts of the body. It also removes carbon dioxide and water that the heart cells produce.
mainData.point5: Circulatory and Digestive system: It provides the heart and other organs in the circulatory system with nutrients so that the heart can keep beating.
mainData.point6: Circulatory and Muscular system: The heart muscles pump blood continuously to all parts of the body. Smooth muscles located in veins and arteries push blood through them with each heartbeat.

mainData.concepts: What are the differences between the transport systems in animals and plants?
mainData.point1: The function of the circulatory system in animals is to transport materials thought the body of the animal but the functions of the circulatory system in animals is to transport materials throughout the body of the plant and to support the plant.
mainData.point2: Materials transported by the circulatory system in animals is oxygen and carbon dioxide, digested food and water while the materials transported by the transport system in plants is water and minerals from roots, food from leaves.
mainData.point3: Liquid flowing in the circulatory system in animals is blood while in plants is sap.
mainData.point4: Tubes through which liquid flows in animals is arteries, veins and capillaries while in plants it is water-carrying tubes(xylem) and food-carrying tubes(phloem).
mainData.point5: Organs that pumps the liquid through the tubes in animals is the heart while there is none in plants.

mainData.point1: All living things are made up of one more cells.
mainData.point2: A cell is the smallest unit of life. It is able to grow, take in food, reproduce changes in the environment.
mainData.point3: All living things begin as a single cell.
mainData.point4: Calls come in different shapes, sizes and structures to suit their specialised functions.
mainData.point5: Most cells are too small to be seen with the naked eye. To be able to see thee cells, we need a microscope.
mainData.point6: The simplest living organism have only one cell (unicellular).
mainData.point7: Examples of unicellular organisms are bacteria, yeast and paramecia.
mainData.point8: Organisms made of many cells are called multicellular organisms.
mainData.point9: When many of the same type of cells group together it forms a tissue. When many of the same type of the tissues group together form a organ. When different organs are connected to one another to work together it forms a system.

mainData.point1: The fuction of a microscope is to help us see objects that are too small to be seen with the naked eye.
mainData.point2: The common light microscope uses a system of lenses to magnify the specimen. The specimen is the object we would like to see.

mainData.concepts: What are the different parts of animal and plant cells?
mainData.point1: An animal cell has a nucleus, cytoplasm and cell membrane.
mainData.point2: An animal cell has no chloroplasts and cell wall.
mainData.point3: A plant cell has a nucleus, cytoplasm, cell membrane, chloroplasts and cell wall.

mainData.concepts: What are the functions of the different parts of a cell?
mainData.point1: Cytoplasm is present in both the animal and plant cell. The cytoplasm is a jelly-like substance that contains many cell parts. The cytoplasm allows substances to move around within the cell.
mainData.point2: Nucleus is present in both the animal and plant cell. Nucleus is a round or oval cell part inside the cytoplasm. The nucleus controls everything that happens inside the cell. It also contains information that is passed on from one generation to another.
mainData.point3: Cell membrane is present in both the animal and plant cell. The cell membrane is a thin layer that surrounds the cytoplasm. The cell membrane controls the movement of materials doing into and out of the cell.
mainData.point4: Cell wall is absent in the animal cell but it present in the plant cell. The cell wall is a stiff layer around the cell membrane. It supports and give the plant cell its shape.
mainData.point5: Chloroplast is absent in the animal cell but present in the plant cell. The chloroplast is a tiny disc-like cell part that contains a green pigment called chlorophyll. It captures sunlight for plant to make food.

mainData.point1: Electricity is a form of energy
mainData.point2: It can be used in electrical equipment to produce other forms of energy such as heat and light
mainData.point3: The path through which electricity flows is the electric circuit
mainData.point4: Examples of equipment that need electricity to work are toaster, oven, iron, hairdryer, lamp, television and computer.
mainData.point5: Things that use electricity have a number of components inside them
mainData.point6: These components make up an electrical system
mainData.point7: Like the human systems, each component in a elctrical system plays an important role in helping function properly

mainData.concepts: What is a simple electric system made up of?
mainData.point1: An electric circuit is an electrical system
mainData.point2: It is made up of a number of components, including a energy source (For example a battery), wires, bulb and a switch.

mainData.concepts: What is a simple electric system made up of? ( Battery )
mainData.point1: A battery has a positive pole and a negative pole
mainData.point2: When the two poles of the battery are connected in a closed electric circuit, electricity flowed through the circuit
mainData.point3: Batteries are convenient sources of electricity. They are use in small electrical appliances that can be carried around easily, such as cameras, calculators and mobile phones
mainData.point4: Batteries come in different shapes and sizes.

mainData.concepts: What is a simple electric system made up of? ( Wires )
mainData.point1: Electric current normally flows through wires
mainData.point2: Wires are generally made of copper. Copper allows electric current to pass through easily

mainData.concepts: What is a simple electric system made up of? ( Switch )
mainData.point1: A switch is used to control the flow of electric current in a circuit.
mainData.point2: A switch either breaks or completes an electric circuit.
mainData.point3: When the switch is open, there is a gap or break in the electric circuit, Electric current cannot flow through the gap in the circuit.
mainData.point4: When the switch is closed, electric current can flow through the switch, and the circuit is complete.

mainData.concepts: What is a simple electric system made up of? (Bulb)
mainData.point1: A bulb is an electric device that is often used in a circuit.
mainData.point2: It consists of a glass bulb, filament, wire, metal casing and metal tip.
mainData.point3: The glass bulb prevents the filament from being damaged.
mainData.point4: The filament produces light and heat when an electric current passes through.
mainData.point5: The wire connects filaments to metal tip and metal casing.
mainData.point6: The metal casing is connected to other components of the electric circuit.
mainData.point7: The metal tip connected the other components of the electric circuit.
mainData.point8: A bulb shines when its filament becomes very hot and begins to give off light.
mainData.point9: The filament of a bulb is usually made of tungsten.

mainData.concepts: How does electric currrent flow in a circuit? (Types of circuits)
mainData.point1: Closed and open circuits
mainData.point2: Series and parallel circuits

mainData.concepts: How does electric currrent flow in a circuit? (Closed circuit)
mainData.point1: An electric current can only flow in a closed or complete circuit.
mainData.point2: When the components of the circuit are joined to form a complete path for electric current to flow through, the circuit is called a closed circuit
mainData.point3: In a closed circuit, electric current flows from the battery, through the wires to other electrical components(s) and back into the battery
mainData.point4: A circuit cqan only be complete when all the components are properly connected

mainData.concepts: How does electric currrent flow in a circuit? (Open circuit)
mainData.point1: When the xomponents of a circuit are not properly connected, there may be a break. or a gap in the circuit
mainData.point2: When that happens, electric current cannot pass through the gap. The path that the electric current flows through is broken and the circuit is a open circuit
mainData.point3: A switch can be used to close or open a circuit

mainData.concepts: How does electric currrent flow in a circuit? (Connections in a bulb)
mainData.point1: A bulb will light up when we use wires to connect it properly to a working battery
mainData.point2: There are two ways to connect a bulb to a battery
mainData.point3: When the metal tip and the metal cading of the bulb are connected to different poles of the bettery, the bulb lights up
mainData.point4: This is because there is a complete circuit for electric current to flow between the poles of the battery
mainData.point5: The bulb will now light up id either the metal the metal tip or the metal casing is not connected to the battery or the bulb blows

mainData.concepts: How does electric current flow in a circuit? (Series and parallel circuits)
mainData.point1: A series circuit is a circuit with only one path for electric current to flow through
mainData.point2: If two bulbs are connected in a series and one of the bulbs is either removed or had blown, the circuit will not work. This is because the circuit is open
mainData.point3: An example of a series circuit is a string of Christmas lights. If any of the bulbs is missing or has blown, electric current will not flow and none of the lights within the series will work.
mainData.point4: A parallel circuit has more than one path for electric current to flow through
mainData.point5: If two bulbs are connected in parallel, one bulb will work when the other is removered or has blown
mainData.point6: An example of a parallel curcuit is the wiring system of a house, If one of the lights blows out, electric current can still floe to the reast of the lights and appliences

mainData.concepts: What are electric conductors and insulators?
mainData.point1: Some materials allow electric current to flow through them , while others do not .
mainData.point2: These properties of materials have to be taken into consideration when choosing materials for making electrical appliances , devices and cables .

mainData.concepts: What are electric conductors and insulators? (Electrical conductors)
mainData.point1: Materials that allow electric current to flow through them are called conductors of electricity or electrical conductors .
mainData.point2: Some electrical conductors conduct electricity better than others . Materials that allow electric current to pass through them easily are called good conductors of electricity
mainData.point3: Most metals are good conductors of electricity. Examples are gols, silver and copper
mainData.point4: Silver is a better electrical conductor that coppper. However, copper is usually ua=sed in current-carrying wires becaue copper is cheaper than silver
mainData.point5: Some liquids also condut electricity. Some examples are calt colution and mercury
mainData.point6: Mercury is a metal that is liquid at room temperature
mainData.point7: Electrical conductors are generally good conductors of heat. Some examples are most metals

mainData.concepts: What are electric conductors and insulators? (Electrical insulators)
mainData.point1: Materials that do not allow electricity to flow through them are called non-conductors of electricity of electrical insulators
mainData.point2: Most non-metals are electrical insulators. Some examples are glass, air, plastic, wood, clay, cloth, paper and cotton
mainData.point3: Most electrical appliances are cased in insulators to prevent electrical shocks. Wires are also covered in plastic or rubber for the same purpose. Materials used for insulating purposes are called insulation.

mainData.concepts: What are electric conductors and insulators? (Circuit tester)
mainData.point1: A circuit tester is used to distinguish between electrical conductors and insulators
mainData.point2: A circuit is a simple electric circuit with a bulb. However, it is an open circuit rather than a closed one
mainData.point3: To test wether a material is a conductor or an insulator, we connect an object made of that material to the circuit
mainData.point4: When an electrical condutor is connected to the circuit, the bulb lights up. This is because the abject closes the gap by allowing electric to flow through it
mainData.point5: When an electrical insulator ic connected to the circuit, the bulb doe not light up. This is because electric current cannot flow through the electrical insulator, so the circuit remains open

mainData.concepts: What are electric conductors and insulators? (Electrical insulators)
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: What are some varibles that can afffect the electric current in a circuit?
mainData.point1: The brightness of the bulb depends on the arrangement of batteries, the number of batteries, the number of bulbs and the arrangement of bulbs.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: Tha batteries in a circuit may be connected in series or parallel
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: When the positive pole of a battery is connected to negative pole of another battery, the batteries are connected in series. This srrangement is commnly used in a torch and a radio
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: When more batteries are connected in series, the bulbs in the circuit shine more brightly. This is because more batteries in series provide more power to the circuit, and more electric current flows through each bulb.
mainData.point2: However, when too many batteries are connected in series to a bulb, the amount of current flowing through the filament may cause the filament to overheat and melt. As a result, the bulb will blow.

mainData.point1: When more bulbs are added to a circuit, the individual bulbs in the circuit shine less brightly. This is because the amount of electric current flowing through each bulb is decreased.
mainData.point2: When one of the bulbs connected in series blows, the other bulb will also not light up, because there is a break in the circuit.

mainData.point1: When bulbs are. arranges in parallel, there are many seperate parts through which the current can flow.
mainData.point2: When more bulbs are added in parallel to the circuit, the individual bulbs in the circuit chine as brightly as before. This is because the electric current flowing through each bulb is still the same, no matter how many bulbs there are in parallel
mainData.point3: Electrical appliances in homes are usually connected in parallel. When one electrical appliance is faulty, electrical current can still flow to other appliances. therefore, the other appliances can still work.

mainData.concepts: Why should we use electricity safely?
mainData.point1: Electricity can be dangerous. Electricity can cause fire and give us electrical shocks.
mainData.point2: Most of the appliances around us run on electricity. It is important that we know how to use electricity and electrical appliances properly
mainData.point3: Common causes of electrical accidents include handling appliances with wet hands, handeling appliances that have damages insulation or overloading power points by plugging in too many electrical appliances at the same time
mainData.point4: Not connecting too many appliances to one socket, making sure wires are not exposed, not touching switches with wet hands, using breakers and fuses and not reparing electrical equipment yourself are ways to use electricity safely

mainData.concepts: How can we use electricity wisely?
mainData.point1: We should conserve electricity so that natural resources such as coal, oil and natural gas can last longer.
mainData.point2: Electricity is usually produced using natural resources, which are materials that we get from earth. Once they are used up, they cannot be replaced quickly.
mainData.point3: The faster we use these natural resources, the faster they run out. When we waste electricity, we indirectly waste these natural resources.
mainData.point4: We pay for electricity. By conserving electricity, we also save money
mainData.point5: We can conserve electricity by turning off all electrical appliances when they are not in use. Use appliances that will turn off automatically when they are not in use or have power-saving features. Use energy-saving light bulbs. They use less electricity but are bright as filament bulbs. Sleeping with lights off or using a small lamp if there is a need to have light on. Not leaving the refrigerator door open for long periods of time. This is because the air in the refrigerator will become warm if the door is left open. A lot of energy will have to be used to cool the refrigerator again. Using a fan instead of a air-conditioner.

mainData.topic: Cycles in plants and animals (Life cycles)
mainData.point1: A life cycle shows the different stages of growth that a living thing goes through
mainData.point2: A life cycle shows how an organism survives and propagates itself
mainData.point3: The life cycle of an animal refers to the different stages of growth from fertilised egg to adult
mainData.point4: Living things reproduce to ensure the survival of their own species When living things become adults. They have the potential to reproduce. Their young will go through similar stages of growth, development and reproduction just as the parents did. Thus, the cycle repeats itself.
mainData.point5: Some young look like (resemble) their parents in many ways but are just smaller in size. Some young look very different from their parents but will look like their parents when they become adults. Most young of animals that go through a 3- stage life cycle resemble their parents.
mainData.point6: Animals whose young look like their parents include: human, cow, elephant, dog, duck, penguin, fish, turtle, cockroach, grasshopper, etc.
mainData.point7: Animals whose young do not look like their parents include: frog, toad, butterfly, mosquito, bee, housefly, mealworm beetle, etc.
mainData.point8: Different animals have different stages if growth adn developement, Some living things have more stages in their life cycle than others. Some life cycle are short and some are long

mainData.topic: Cycles in plants and animals (Life cycles)
mainData.point1: The chicken has 3 stages in its life cycle.
mainData.point2: The egg is fertilised in the hen's body.
mainData.point3: The hen lays the egg and keeps the egg warn bt sitting on it.
mainData.point4: The hen lays the egg and keeps the egg warn bt sitting on it.
mainData.point5: The egg yolk provides food for the developing chick.
mainData.point6: The egg takes three weeks or 21 days to develop into a chick.
mainData.point7: In chicken farms, incubators are used to artificially hatch eggs. The temperature is set at 41ºc to help the embryo inside the egg develop.

mainData.topic: Cycles in plants and animals (Life cycles)
mainData.point1: The grasshopper has 3 stages in its life cycle.
mainData.point2: The female grasshopper lays eggs in a hole in the sand. She produces a liquid which hardens to form a case around the eggs, thus preventing predators from eating them.
mainData.point3: It takes about two weeks for the eggs to develop into nymphs.
mainData.point4: The nymphs resemble adults but are smaller in size and have no wings
mainData.point5: Each nymph moults ( shedding its old skin and growings new one ) about five times as it grows into an adult.

mainData.topic: Cycles in plants and animals (Life cycles)
mainData.point1: The coachroach has 3 stages in its life cycle.
mainData.point2: The female cockroach lays 16 to 40 eggs in a hard, brown egg case in dark and warm places.
mainData.point3: It takes about 6 to 7 weeks for the eggs to develop into nymphs.
mainData.point4: The nymphs resemble adults but are smaller in size and have no wings
mainData.point5: Each nymph moults ( shedding its old skin and growings new one ) several times as it grows in size, changing to a darker shade of brown and growing wings.

mainData.topic: Cycles in plants and animals (Life cycles)
mainData.point1: The mosquito has 4 stages in its life cycle.
mainData.point2: The female mosquito lays eggs on the surface of still or stagnant water.
mainData.point3: It takes about 14 to 16 days for the mosquito to develop from egg to adult.  Eggs hatch into larvae in 2 to 3 days.
mainData.point4: A larva is also known as a wriggler. Wrigglers look very different from adults.
mainData.point5: They feed on tiny food particles and microscopic organisms in the water. They breathe through a breathing tube. They moult several times and grow rapidly. After 8 to 10 days, the larva becomes a pupa.
mainData.point6: A pupa is comma-shaped and does not feed or move. It hangs itself just under the water surface by its breathing tube. Adult structures develop and in 1 to 2 days, an adult emerges from the pupa.
mainData.point7: Mosquitoes can spread diseases like malaria, dengue fever and yellow fever. Being small and having the ability to fly makes it difficult to destroy them. Hence, the easiest way to kill them is to destroy their breeding grounds while they are still in the larva and pupa stages.
mainData.point8: The female mosquito lays eggs on the surface of still or stagnant water.

mainData.topic: Cycles in plants and animals (Life cycles)
mainData.point1: The frog has 3 stages in its life cycle.
mainData.point2: The female frog lays eggs in water, and a male frog fertilises them.
mainData.point3: Eggs are laid in masses and are covered with a smelly jelly-like substance that repels predators, thus preventing the eggs from being eaten up.
mainData.point4: It takes about two weeks for eggs to develop into tadpoles, which do not resemble their parents. They breathe through gills at this stage, feeding on tiny plants and algae. The hind legs grow first, followed by the front legs about four weeks later. Lungs then slowly develop and  replace the gills.
mainData.point5: The young frog's tail shortens and it now resembles the adult. goes to the water surface to breathe, using its lungs. As an adult, the lungs become fully developed and its tail and gills have completely 'disappeared'.
mainData.point6: The adult also uses its moist skin to breathe when in water.
mainData.point7: Depending on the species, it can take a few months to a year for the frogs develop from tadpoles to adults.
mainData.point8: The life cycle of a toad is similar to a frog's but the toad's eggs are laid in a string.

mainData.topic: Cycles in plants and animals (Life cycles)
mainData.point1: The butterfly has 4 stages in its life cycle.
mainData.point2: It takes about 40 days to develop from an egg an adult
mainData.point3: The female butterfly lays eggs in batches of 10 to 100 on the underside of the leaves where its young can get food easily and where there is less chance of being detected by predators. The embryo inside the egg gets nutrients from the yolk. The larva that hatches from the egg feeds on its eggshell and the leaf on which it is hatched.
mainData.point4: The cocoon splits and the adult butterfly emerges. It takes about 2 hours for its moist and soft, crumpled wings to dry, harden and spread out before it flying.

mainData.topic: Cycles in plants and animals (Life cycles)
mainData.point1: The mealworm beetle has 4 stages in its life cycle.
mainData.point2: It takes about 100 days for the egg to develop into an adult.
mainData.point3: The female mealworm beetle lays tiny white eggs (on land). The eggs hatch into cream-coloured larvae in 7 days. The larva is also known as the mealworm, which grows rapidly and moults up to 15 times. Each larva is about 3 mm long and has a small head and a pair of short feelers. It feeds on cereals, grains or breads.
mainData.point4: After about 3 months, it becomes a pupa. At the pupa stage, it does not feed or move. Adult structures develop and in 7 to 8 days, the adult mealworm beetle emerges out of the case.

mainData.topic: Cycles in plants and animals (Life cycles)
mainData.point1: It takes about 11 days to develop for the egg to develop into an adult.
mainData.point2: Fertilised eggs are laid on food, faeces, rotting flesh and other warm organic material.
mainData.point3: The young of houseflies are known as maggots. Maggots have no wings and cannot fly. Maggots have no compound eyes and they feed on the material their eggs were laid on (usually rotting meat). Pupation six days (depending on species) and during this process the young develops wings and compound eyes.
mainData.point4: The adult housefly develops fully and emerges from its cocoon.

mainData.topic: Cycles in plants and animals (Life cycles)
mainData.concepts: Life cycles of Flowering Plants and Ferns
mainData.point1: The life cycle of a plant shows the different stages of development or growth of a seed or other plant parts into an adult plant.
mainData.point2: Most flowering plants reproduce from seeds.
mainData.point3: Seeds of flowering plants are usually found inside the fruits. Each seed contains a baby plant that is protected by seed leaves. The seed leaves provide food for the germinating seed until it is able to make its own food when its green leaves sprout.
mainData.point4: When a seed starts to grow, it germinates. Seeds require air, warmth and water to germinate.
mainData.point5: When the seed germinates, its roots will appear first. Roots absorb water and nutrients from the soil for the baby plant. Once the roots have started growing, the shoot will appear and leaves will start to sprout.
mainData.point6: The seedling (young plant) is able to make its own food when its first leaves appear. At this stage and onwards, the plant needs sunlight to grow.
mainData.point7: As it matures, the young plant grows into an adult plant. Adult flowering plants bear flowers.
mainData.point8: Flowers, when fertilised, develop into fruits. These fruits contain seeds that can grow into new plants, thus starting a new cycle.
mainData.point9: Ferns grow from spores. Each spore is able to grow into a fern.

mainData.point1: All living and non-living things are made of matter.
mainData.point2: Matter is anything that has mass and occupies space. the amount of substance in an object.
mainData.point3: Mass is measured in kilograms (kg) or grams (g). Mass can be measured using an electronic scale or a triple beam balance. A lever balance can be used to measure mass too but is more often used to compare the masses of 2 or more objects.
mainData.point4: Volume is the amount of space an object or substance occupies. Hence, the amount of space a matter occupies is measured by its volume.
mainData.point5: Volume is commonly measured in cubic centimetre (cm³), cubic metres (m³), millilitres (ml) or litres (l).
mainData.point6: 1 mł = 1 cm ³ and 1 l = 1000 ml = 1000 cm³
mainData.point7: Volume can be measured using a beaker or measuring cylinder for liquids or irregular-shaped solids. For regular solids such as a cube or cuboid, formulae such as Length x Breadth x Height can be used.
mainData.point8: Matter can be visible or invisible Matter that is visible to us includes living things like tigers, ants, trees and non- living things like sand, eraser and tables. Matter that is invisible to us includes air, which is a mixture of gases. Wind, which actually is moving air, cannot be seen.
mainData.point9: Non-matter does not have mass. Neither does it occupy space. Examples of non-matter include sunlight, shadow, sound, light, electricity, heat, fire, radio waves, etc.

mainData.concepts: The 3 states of matter and examples
mainData.point1: Matter can exist in 3 states.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: The 3 states of matter and examples - Solid state
mainData.point1: Matter in the solid state are known as solids.
mainData.point2: Examples are a cup, pencil, lorry, chair, book, brick, sand, copper, leaf, wood, ice and dry ice (frozen carbon dioxide)

mainData.concepts: The 3 states of matter and examples - Liquid state
mainData.point1: Matter in the liquid state are known as liquids.
mainData.point2: Examples are water, milk, petroleum, coffee, oil, orange juice, kerosene, and mercury (liquid metal)

mainData.concepts: The 3 states of matter and examples - Gaseous state
mainData.point1: Matter in the gaseous state are known as gases.
mainData.point2: Examples are water vapour, nitrogen, oxygen, hydrogen, carbon dioxide, helium (used to fill balloons that float in the air) and neon.

mainData.concepts: The characteristics of Solids, Liquids and Gases
mainData.point1: The characteristics of Solids, Liquids and Gases
mainData.point2: All 3 states of matter (solids, liquids and gases) have mass and occupy space.

mainData.point1: A solid has a definite (or fixed) shape and a definite volume.
mainData.point2: A solid cannot be compressed.

mainData.point1: Has definite shape
mainData.point2: A solid does not change its shape by itself. E.g. a car, a pencil, a bowl, rock, table, etc.
mainData.point3: The shape of solids are only changed with the application of external force. E.g. a piece of rock that has been sculpted into a statue, a sheet of paper that has been folded into a crane

mainData.point1: Has definite volume / Cannot be compressed
mainData.point2: A solid's volume or the amount of space it occupies will always remain the same.
mainData.point3: This means that the volume of a solid cannot be changed or compressed to occupy a smaller space.
mainData.point4: If a box (the space) can hold exactly 6 wooden blocks (solids), we cannot squeeze or change the volume of the blocks to pack more blocks into the box.

mainData.point1: A liquid has a definite volume but NO definite shape.
mainData.point2: Having a definite volume means that a liquid cannot be compressed.

mainData.point1: No definite shape
mainData.point2: Liquid takes the shape of its container.

mainData.point1: Has definite volume
mainData.point2: A liquid's volume or the amount of space occupies is fixed.
mainData.point3: This means that the volume remains the same regardless of the shape of containers it is in.
mainData.point4: Just like a solid, a liquid cannot be compressed. It cannot be made to occupy a smaller space or volume.
mainData.point5: If we try in pour in some more water into a glass is that is already completely filled with water, the water will overflow from the glass.

mainData.point1: A gas has no definite shape and no definite volume.
mainData.point2: A gas can be compressed

mainData.point1: Has no definite shape
mainData.point2: A gas takes the shape of its container.
mainData.point4: As you blow air into a balloon, the air inflates the balloon and will occupy a space that is controlled by the shape of the balloon. A similar example is pumping air into a soccer ball.

mainData.point1: Has no definite volume
mainData.point2: The volume of a gas is not always the same (i.e. not constant).
mainData.point3: It occupies completely the space in which it is kept.
mainData.point4: The volume of a gas can be changed. It can be either compressed to occupy a smaller space or spread out to occupy a bigger space.
mainData.point5: Under normal atmospheric conditions, a certain amount of air will occupy a fixed volume of space. However, this volume of air can be increased by applying pressure or reduced by decreasing pressure.

mainData.concepts: Differences among Solids, Liquids and Gases
mainData.point1: Has Definite shape?
mainData.point2: Solid has a definite shape but both liquid and gas do not have a definite shape

mainData.concepts: Differences among Solids, Liquids and Gases
mainData.point1: Has Definite volume?
mainData.point2: Gas can be compressed but both solid and liquid cannot be compressed.

mainData.concepts: Differences among Solids, Liquids and Gases
mainData.point1: Can be compressed?
mainData.point2: Both solid and liquid have a definite volume but gas does not have a definite volume

mainData.concepts: Differences among Solids, Liquids and Gases
mainData.point1: Types of solid
mainData.point2: Soft solids change their shapes more easily compared to hard solids. For instance, a table cloth forms the shape of the tabletop but not the other way around. These are due to external forces acting on the cloth which includes gravity and friction.
mainData.point3: Solids can appear to flow like liquids and gases as well as take up the shapes of containers if each single part is very small, like sand, sugar and flour. In an hourglass, extremely fine grains of sand flow easily from the top to the bottom compartment. The shape each grain of sand actually remains the same but this is not observable as the grains are too tiny.

mainData.concepts: Differences among Solids, Liquids and Gases
mainData.point1: Solids and liquids that are less dense* than water will float and those that are denser than water will sink.
mainData.point2: Solids that float on water: cork, ice, most types of wood
mainData.point3: Solids that sink in water: rock, ice, ceramic, glass, brick, most metals
mainData.point4: Liquids that float on water: oil, petrol, turpentine
mainData.point5: Liquids that sink in water: mercury, honey
mainData.point6: Density is not about how heavy an object is. For instance, heavy (tree) logs are transported by river as they can float while a very light paper clip will sink in water. This is because when a log is cut down to the size of a paper clip (if it is possible), the amount of matter in that space is less than that contained in the paper clip. This means that the log is less dense than the paper clip.

mainData.concepts: Differences among Solids, Liquids and Gases
mainData.point1: The different viscosities (the degree of thickness and 'stickiness') of liquids affect their movement or ease of flow. Paint, glue and latex (liquids with high viscosity) flow slower while water and turpentine (liquids with low viscosity) flow faster.
mainData.point2: When poured, honey flows out of a cup more slowly than water because it has a higher viscosity. The water will also "break apart" and splash about more as water is less sticky.

mainData.point1: A system is made up of different parts that work together to perform a specific job or function.
mainData.point2: Each part in a system has its own function(s). Different parts work together to enable the system to carry out its specific function.
mainData.point3: Every living thing is a system made up of many parts.

mainData.point1: A plant is a complex system as it is made up of flower many parts.
mainData.point2: Most plants have parts such as roots, stems, stem leaves, flowers, fruits and seeds
mainData.point3: Each part of the plant performs a different task to help the plant to survive and ensure the continuity of its own kind.
mainData.point4: The flowers, fruits and seeds make up the plant's reproductive system.
mainData.point5: Seeds grow into a new plant.
mainData.point6: Roots anchors the plant firmly to the soil and absorbs water and mineral salts from the soil.
mainData.point7: The stem supports the plant, ensures that the branches and leaves are spread out to obtain maximum sunlight, transports water and mineral salts from root to the other parts of the plant via water-carrying tubes and transports food made in the leaves to other parts of the plant via food-carrying tubes.
mainData.point8: The leaf make food through the process of photosynthesis. It also has tiny openings (stomata) that allows the plant to carry out gaseous exchange ( oxygen and carbon dioxide) with its surroundings and it also loses excess water through respiration.
mainData.point9: The flowers has colourful petals that attract insects that help in pollination. The female flower develops into fruits upon fertilisation.
mainData.point10: The fruit contains seeds for reproduction and it either releases or scatters seeds.
mainData.point11: Stomata are mostly found on the underside of the leaf, but some are also present on the upper surface of the leaf and on the stem.
mainData.point12: Stomata (singular: stoma) allow the gaseous exchange of carbon dioxide and oxygen to take place between the plant and the surroundings. They also allow excess water to escape through the process of transpiration.
mainData.point13: Most leaves are green because they have a green pigment called chlorophyll.
mainData.point14: Chlorophyll traps light energy from the Sun. This light energy is used by the leaves to convert carbon dioxide and water into food (in the form of sugar). This process is known as photosynthesis, in which oxygen is a by- product.
mainData.point15: The sugar that the plant produces is the food that provides energy for growth and other activities in the plant.
mainData.point16: There are 2 separate tubes that transport different materials within a plant. Water-carrying tubes transport water and mineral salts from the roots to other parts of the plant. Food-carrying tubes transport food produced by the leaves to other parts of the plant.
mainData.point17: Leaves and branches are spread out to absorb as much sunlight as possible. The leaves and branches of plants are arranged with minimal overlap so that each individual leaf can absorb as much sunlight as possible.
mainData.point18: During the day, a green plant needs to take in carbon dioxide in order to photosynthesise. However, it also takes in oxygen for the process known as respiration.
mainData.point19: Water + Carbon Dioxide –––––(in presence of light and chlorophyll)–––––––> Oxygen + Food (Glucose)

mainData.concepts: Why are plants important to living things
mainData.point1: Plants are important to living things as they provide us with food, replenish the air with the oxygen that they produce during photosynthesis, provide shelter, provide protection for some animals, beautify our surrounds, can be used as materials for making furniture and have roots that hold the soil together, thus helping to reduce soil erosion.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: An introduction to Human Body systems
mainData.point1: A system is a group of different but connected parts working together to carry out a specific function.
mainData.point2: Like plants, humans have different parts to carry out different jobs and activities. The human body comprises many organ systems.
mainData.point3: An organ system is made up of two or more organs working together to perform a major body function.
mainData.point4: Organs are the parts of humans that perform important and specific functions.
mainData.point5: An organ is made up of tissues that work together to perform a specific activity.
mainData.point6: Tissues are made up of cells, which are the basic units of life (more details on cells in Primary 5).
mainData.point7: The sense organs in humans help us detect and respond to changes in our environment.
mainData.point8: The brain ensures that all the systems work well together. It controls all the activities within the human body.

mainData.concepts: The sensory system - The 5 sense organs, what they sense and their functions
mainData.point1: The human sensory system is made up of 5 main sense organs that gather information from the surroundings. This system detects and responds to changes around us.
mainData.point2: The information gathered is transmitted or sent to our brain through a network of nerves. The brain assesses this information, decides what to do and then sends instructions to the rest of the body on the appropriate action to take.
mainData.point3: The eyes has a sense of light
mainData.point4: The ears have a sense of hearing
mainData.point5: The nose has a sense of smell
mainData.point6: The tongue has a sense of taste
mainData.point7: The skin has a sense of touch

mainData.concepts: The 5 main systems of our body
mainData.point1: The 5 main systems of our body work together to keep us alive, and enables us to move around, grow and carry out our daily tasks. Their functions are:

mainData.concepts: The 5 main systems of our body - Digestive system
mainData.point1: The digestive system breaks down food into simpler substances and absorbs digested food that is needed by the body
mainData.point2: The digestive system is made up of the mouth, gullet, stomach, small intestine and anus.

mainData.concepts: The 5 main systems of our body - Circulatory system
mainData.point1: The circulatory system carries digested food, water and oxygen to all parts of the body and carries wastes away from different parts of the body
mainData.point2: The circulatory system is made up of the heart, blood vessels and blood

mainData.concepts: The 5 main systems of our body - Respiratory system
mainData.point1: The respiratory system enables gaseous exchange between the body and the environment and obtains oxygen from the environment and removes carbon dioxide from the body
mainData.point2: The respiratory system is made of the nose, mouth, windpipe, bronchi and lungs.

mainData.concepts: The 5 main systems of our body - Skeletal system
mainData.point1: The skeletal system supports the body and gives it shape. It also protects important organs and works with the muscular system to enable movement.
mainData.point2: The skeletal system consists of bones.

mainData.concepts: The 5 main systems of our body - Muscular system
mainData.point1: The muscular system enables movement by working with the skeletal system.
mainData.point2: The muscular system consists of muscles.

mainData.point1: When we are hungry, we eat. The food we eat gives us energy to carry out lme processes.
mainData.point2: The digestive system helps us to break down food into simpler substances that our body can absorb.
mainData.point3: Digested food is absorbed by the blood and is use to produce energy while not digested food moves through the system and is removed from the body.
mainData.point4: The human digestive system is made up of 5 main parts, the mouth, gullet, stomach, small intestine and the large intestine.
mainData.point5: Waste is stored at the end of the large intestine (rectum) and then released through the anus.

mainData.point1: The process of digestion starts in the mouth.
mainData.point2: Digestion of food takes placo only at 3 places - the mouth, stomach and small intestine
mainData.point3: Path taken by food: Mouth -> Gullet -> Stomach -> Small intestine -> Large intestine -> anus and rectum

mainData.point1: Digestion of food starts in the mouth
mainData.point2: When we chew. our teeth grinds food down into smaller pieces.
mainData.point3: The incisors (the flat, sharp teeth at the front of the mouth) cut and slice the food into smaller pieces.
mainData.point4: The molars (the broad, round teeth at the back of the mouth) mash and crush the food into even smaller pieces.
mainData.point5: The tongue mixes the food with saliva. Besides wetting and lubricating the food so that it can go down the gullet more smoothly, saliva also contains a digestive juice that starts breaking down some of the food. The tongue shapes the food into a small ball, which is then swallowed.

mainData.point1: Food swallowed in the mouth goes down a tube called the gullet of oesophagus.
mainData.point2: The muscles in the walls of the gullet push the food down to the stomach

mainData.point1: Here, more digestive juices are added and muscles around the stomach move and churn the food. After two to five hours, the solid food is partially digested into a porridge-like form,
mainData.point2: This partly digested food then leaves the stomach and enters the small intestine.

mainData.point1: The small intestine secretes more digestive juices to digest as much of the remaining food as possible.
mainData.point2: Digested food is absorbed into the bloodstream through tiny blood vessels around the walls of the small intestine,
mainData.point3: The blood in the blood vessels transports the digested food to other parts of the body to be converted into energy for life processes
mainData.point4: The small intestine is very long and has many folds (creases) to increase its surface area and increase the absorption rate of digested food

mainData.point1: The remaining food that is undigested enters a wider tube called the large intestine. This is shorter but wider than the small intestine.
mainData.point2: Water and some minerals are absorbed from the undigested food into the bloodstream,
mainData.point3: The remaining undigested food becomes partially solid and is temporarily stored in the lower part of the large intestine called the rectum.
mainData.point4: The partially solid waste is finally passed out from the body through the anus as faeces.

mainData.point1: The supporting framework of our body is know as the skeleton
mainData.point2: Our skeleton supports our body, gives us our body shape and protects the delicate and important organs in our body such as the brain, heart, lungs, spinal cord and pelvis.

mainData.point1: Our bones cannot move on their own.
mainData.point2: Muscles enable us to move different parts of our body.
mainData.point3: Our muscular system is made up of muscles. They make up most of the fleshy part of our body. They are tissues made fo cells.
mainData.point4: Muscles that are attached to bones pull on bones to make them move
mainData.point5: Muscles usually work in pairs but can work singly also.
mainData.point6: The movement of bones is achieved through the contraction and relaxation of muscles

mainData.topic: What is a magnet? Natural and artificial magnets, shapes of magnets
mainData.concepts: A magnet is an object that can attract or pull things made of iron, steel, nickel and cobalt.
mainData.point1: Magnets can be natural (found in nature) or artificial (man-made).
mainData.point2: Natural magnets are found naturally in iron ores, which are found in different parts of the Earth's crust.
mainData.point3: Natural magnets are known as lodestones or magnetite.
mainData.point4: Artificial or man-made magnets are made from iron or alloys of certain metals including iron, steel, cobalt and nickel. ("Alloy refers to a mixture of metals or of metals and non-metals. For example, steel is an alloy of iron and carbon.)
mainData.point5: Most magnets are man-made. They can be made into many different sizes and shapes in order to suit their different uses.
mainData.point6: The 7 common types of magnets are ber magnet, strip magnet, ring magnet, button magnet, horseshoe magnet, U-shaped magnet and rod magnet.

mainData.concepts: Materials that can be attracted by magnets are known as magnetic materials.
mainData.point1: Not all metals are magnetic. The magnetic metals are iron, steel, nickel and cobalt or their alloys.
mainData.point2: Materials that are not attracted to magnets are known as non-magnetic materials. Most metals and all non-metals are not attracted to magnets.
mainData.point3: Magnetic materials that are pure metal: Iron,Cobalt,Nickel
mainData.point4: Magnetic materials that are alloys: Steel
mainData.point5: Non-magnetic materials that are metala: Gold, silver, aluminum, zinc, copper
mainData.point6: Non-magnetic materials that are non-metals: cotton, silk, wood, plastic, glass, ect.
mainData.point7: Examples of magnetic objects are: seal of a fridge door, car, paper clip and screw
mainData.point8: Examples of non-magnetic objects are: football, glass, flower and paper
mainData.point9: Knowing which materials are magnetic or non-magnetic helps us identify the types of materials that allow magnetism to pass through.
mainData.point10: The following shows what happens when a magnetic or non-magnetic material is placed between the magnet and a screw:

mainData.point1: All magnets have a North pole and a South pole
mainData.point2: A magnet is strongest at its poles
mainData.point3: Magnets rest in the North-South direction when freely-suspended

mainData.point1: Magnets attract magnetic materials that are made of iron, steel, nickel and cobalt or their alloys (explained earlier).
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: All magnets have a North pole and a South pole
mainData.point1: The 2 ends of a magnet are called its poles.
mainData.point2: Regardless of their shapes, all magnets have 2 poles - the North-seeking pole and the South-seeking pole. In short, they can be named the North (N) and South (S) poles respectively.
mainData.point3: When a magnet is broken into smaller pieces, each broken piece itself becomes a smaller magnet.
mainData.point4: Each broken magnet has its own N-pole and S-pole.

mainData.concepts: A magnet is strongest at its poles
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Magnets rest in the North-South direction when freely-suspended
mainData.point1: Magnets aligned themselves in the north south direction when they are free suspended
mainData.point2: "Freely suspend" means that magnet is allowed to move and rotate freely until it rests in a particular direction. The magnet can be balanced and hang on a thin and soft string are placed on a non-magnetic floating object in water.
mainData.point3: The bar magnets will come to rest in a North-South direction after a few minutes
mainData.point4: A compass can be used to tell directions because the compass needle acts as a freely suspended magnet. It will always rest in the North-South direction unless it is close to another magnet or magnetic material.
mainData.point5: Soldiers, Sailors and hikers use compasses to navigate.

mainData.point1: Two similar or like poles repel each other when they are brought into close contact. The poles push each other away. This is known as magnetic repulsion.
mainData.point2: This means that when 2 south-poles or 2 north-poles are brought close to each other, they exert magnetic force that push each other away.

mainData.point1: 2 dissimilar or unlike poles will attract each other when they are brought into close contact. .
mainData.point2: This means that when the South Pole of a magnet is facing the North Pole of another magnet the exert magnetic force that pull them towards each other.

mainData.concepts: To ensure that permanent magnets retain your magnetism for a longer time, they should be stored properly
mainData.point1: For a horseshoe magnet, a single flat piece of soft iron called the keeper is placed across both poles of the magnet
mainData.point2: The keeper is usually made from soft iron or steel
mainData.point3: Bar magnets should be stored in pairs with the opposite poles placed next to each other. A keeper is placed across the opposite poles on each end.

mainData.concepts: An ordinary object can be made into a magnet if it is or contains a magnetic material.
mainData.point1: There are 3 ways of making a temporary magnet, namely by stroking, electrical and induction.
mainData.point2: Stroking method when a magnetic material is stroked with a magnet enough times, it becomes a temporary magnet. The more times it is stroked, the stronger the temporary magnet.
mainData.point3: Electrical method - when an electrical current is passed through a wire coiled around a magnetic material, the magnetic material becomes a temporary magnet. It is call an electromagnet. The greater the source of electrical power, the stronger the magnet becomes. Increasing the number of coils will also increase the strength of the magnet.
mainData.point4: Induction method - a magnetic object can also be turned into a temporary magnet when it is near or in contact with a magnet. Its magnetic strength will vary according to the strength of the magnet.
mainData.point5: The magnetism that is created in objects using the methods described above is not permanent.
mainData.point6: For the induction method, the iron nail will not be able to attract any magnetic substances once the strong magnet is removed. For the electrical method, the electromagnet loses its magnetism the moment the current is switched off.
mainData.point7: 2 types of artificial (man-made) magnets can be made:
mainData.point8: Temporary magnets lose their magnetism easily and is usually made of mild steel or iron. Electromagnets are commonly used in products where its property of being magnetized when there is supply electricity can be put to good use, for example electric bells and motors
mainData.point9: Permanent magnets retain magnetism for longer periods of time and is usually made of hard steel or alloys of steel, nickel or cobalt. Permanent magnets are used in compasses, as magnetic strip in credit and ATM cards, in speakers and microphones.

mainData.topic: Strength of magnets and 3 ways of demagnetising a magnet.
mainData.point1: One way to compare the strength of magnets is to observe the number of identical magnetic objects they are able to attract (and hold on to).
mainData.point2: A magnet's strength depends on the material that it is made from.
mainData.point3: Magnets made of mixtures or alloys of cobalt, nickel and iron are stronger than those made of purely iron or steel,
mainData.point4: A magnet can be made to lose its magnetism. The weakened magnet is said to be demagnetised.
mainData.point5: A magnet can lose its magnetism by hitting/dropping it, by heating or by using a demagnetiser.

mainData.topic: Uses of magnetism in homes and industries
mainData.point1: A long thin strip of magnet keeps the door of the refrigerator shut
mainData.point2: A magnet in doorstep that attracts the magnetic object attached to the door to keep the door from swinging
mainData.point3: A button magnet keeps handbag closed
mainData.point4: Magnets are used to fast and paper no messages or small objects on magnetic boards or refrigerators
mainData.point5: Travel chess sets have chess pieces with magnets to keep them from falling over easily

mainData.topic: Uses of magnetism in homes and industries
mainData.point1: Strong magnets are used to lift heavy iron and steel bars in construction sites
mainData.point2: Cranes with giant electromagnets I used to live containers and other objects made from iron or steel

mainData.topic: Uses of magnetism in homes and industries
mainData.point1: The needle of a compass is a freely-suspended magnet that turns freely and always aligns itself in the north-south direction

mainData.topic: Uses of magnetism in homes and industries
mainData.concepts: separating magnetic material from non-magnetic material
mainData.point1: Strong magnets are used to separate scraps of iron and steel in incinerators.
mainData.point2: In scrapyards and recycling plants, useful scraps of iron or steel that can be reused are picked up from the rest of the materials when they are moved past a strong magnet.

mainData.topic: Uses of magnetism in homes and industries
mainData.point1: Magnetic materials used in are computer floppy disks, cassette tapes and video tapes.
mainData.point2: Magnetic strips are used in credit cards, ATM cards and EZ-Link cards to store information.

mainData.topic: Uses of magnetism in homes and industries
mainData.point1: Electromagnets are used in telephones, doorbells and loudspeakers to create and transmit sounds.

mainData.topic: Living and Non-living Things: Classification of Things
mainData.point1: The great variety of things around us can be classified according to their observable properties, nature, behaviours, inter-relationships and functions.
mainData.point2: In general, things around us can be classified into two main groups. Example: Living things, Non-living things

mainData.topic: Living and Non-living Things: Classification of Things
mainData.point1: Living things are things which are alive.
mainData.point2: They are classified into four main groups. They include Animals, Plants, Fungi and Bacteria

mainData.topic: Living and Non-living Things: Classification of Things
mainData.point1: Animals can be found on land and in water.
mainData.point2: Some examples of animals living on land are Elephants and Tigers.
mainData.point3: Some examples of animals living in water are Dolphins and Angelfishes
mainData.point4: Some animals living both on land and in water are Crocodiles and frogs.
mainData.point5: Animals come in different shapes, colours and sizes.
mainData.point6: They move in different ways like Jumping, galloping or swimming
mainData.point7: They have different outer coverings like Scales, feathers or hair
mainData.point8: They reproduce either by laying eggs or giving birth to young alive.

mainData.topic: Living and Non-living Things: Classification of Things
mainData.point1: Plants grow on land and in water.
mainData.point2: Some examples of land plants are Balsam plants and Cactus
mainData.point3: Some examples of water plants are Arrowheads and Duckweeds.
mainData.point4: Plants grown in water can be floating on water, partially submerged in water or completely submerged in water.
mainData.point5: They come in different shapes and sizes.
mainData.point6: They can make their own food because they have chlorophyll in their leaves.

mainData.topic: Living and Non-living Things: Classification of Things
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Fungi are neither plants nor animals.
mainData.point3: They cannot make their own food as they do not have chlorophyll.
mainData.point4: They feed on or grow on plants and animals which are either dead or alive.
mainData.point5: They come in different shapes, colours and sizes.

mainData.topic: Living and Non-living Things: Classification of Things
mainData.point1: Bacteria are micro-organisms.
mainData.point2: Some examples of micro-organisms are Paramecium and Amoeba
mainData.point3: Micro-organisms are very tiny living things that cannot be seen by our naked eyes. we can only look at them through a microscope.
mainData.point4: They can be found almost everywhere: in the air, water, soil, as well as in and on plants and animals.

mainData.topic: Living and Non-living Things: Classification of Things
mainData.point1: Non-living things are things which are not alive.
mainData.point2: They are made of things which are never alive or were once alive.

mainData.topic: Living and Non-living Things: Classification of Things
mainData.point1: Some examples of non-living things which are never alive are Alarm clocks and Scissors.
mainData.point2: They are usually made from the natural materials found on Earth, like Iron, gold and clay
mainData.point3: However, they can also be made from man-made materials such as Nylon, glass and polyester

mainData.topic: Living and Non-living Things: Classification of Things
mainData.point1: Some examples of non-living things which were once alive such as a Wooden chair and Leather bag
mainData.point2: Non-living things can be made from things which were once alive.

mainData.topic: Living and Non-living Things: Classification of Things
mainData.point1: Living things grow
mainData.point2: They can grow in height or length. They also increase in size.
mainData.point3: Their young are generally much smaller than their parents. As they grow, they become bigger and stronger.
mainData.point4: Their young are generally much smaller than their parents. As they grow, they become bigger and stronger. Example, seedling grows into a plant and a chick grows into a hen
mainData.point5: As living things grow, other changes take place too. Example, the young of a toad (a tadpole) does not resemble its parents.
mainData.point6: Living things grow over time. Some living things, such as a baby and a coconut tree, take many years to be fully grown. Others, such as a chick and a bean sprout take a shorter time to be fully grown.

mainData.topic: Living and Non-living Things: Classification of Things
mainData.point1: Unlike living things, non-living things do not grow.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.topic: Living and Non-living Things: Classification of Things
mainData.point1: Living things move by themselves.
mainData.point2: Animals move about in different ways. Example, a butterfly flies, a dolphin swims and a kangaroo hops
mainData.point3: Not all animals move about freely on their own. Example, the sea anemone and coral spend a large part of their lives anchored in one spot.
mainData.point4: Animals can also move certain parts of their bodies. Example, a baby waving her hand and a dog wagging its tail
mainData.point5: Animals move about to get food, water and shelter. They also move to run away from danger. Sometimes, they move in search of mating partners.
mainData.point6: Plants can also move. However, they stay rooted to where they are and can only move certain parts of themselves. Their movements are usually very slow and less obvious as compared to animals. Example, the branches of a potted plant placed in a dark room will grow towards the window where sunlight is.
mainData.point7: Fungi, like plants, stay in one location and do not move as freely as animals. They only move certain parts of themselves.
mainData.point8: Under a microscope, you can see that bacteria also move. Some bacteria move slowly while others move quickly.

mainData.topic: Living and Non-living Things: Classification of Things
mainData.point1: Unlike living things, non-living things are unable to move by themselves.
mainData.point2: Example, a shopping cart changes position due to a woman pushing it.

mainData.topic: Living and Non-living Things: Classification of Things
mainData.point1: Living things respond to changes. Changes in the surroundings are known as stimuli.
mainData.point2: Example, we put a jacket when we feel cold and a snail hides in its shell when touched.

mainData.topic: Living and Non-living Things: Classification of Things
mainData.point1: Unlike living things, non-living things do not respond to stimuli. However, they may react.
mainData.point2: Example, ice melts when it gains heat. Unlike living things, it cannot move to escape from melting.

mainData.topic: Living and Non-living Things: Classification of Things
mainData.point1: Living things die.
mainData.point2: Their deaths may be due to the following: Lack of air, water or food, accident, old age, disease, pollution or eaten up by other living things
mainData.point3: Different living things have different lifespans. Human beings, on average, can live up to 80 years while certain species of trees or plants can live up to a few hundred years.
mainData.point4: When living things die, they no longer have the characteristics of living things.

mainData.topic: Living and Non-living Things: Classification of Things
mainData.point1: Unlike living things, non-living things do not die.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.topic: Living and Non-living Things: Classification of Things
mainData.point1: Living things reproduce.
mainData.point2: Since living things cannot live forever, they reproduce to ensure the survival of their species. This will prevent them from becoming extinct.
mainData.point3: Some animals reproduce by laying eggs. Example, chicken and turtle
mainData.point4: Some animals reproduce by giving birth to their young alive.
mainData.point5: Example, a pig and its piglet or a jaguar and its cub
mainData.point6: Most flowering plants reproduce from seeds. The parent plants produce seeds. When the surrounding conditions are suitable, the seed will grow into a seedling which will then develop into an adult plant that will eventually bear flowers and fruits. Example, life cycle of a plant
mainData.point7: Some plants reproduce by vegetative propagation, a process that involves the growing of new plants from different parts of the parent such as roots, stems and leaves.
mainData.point8: Non-flowering plants reproduce by spores. Spores are very thin in size but like seeds, each spore can develop into a new plant. Example, moss and fern

mainData.point1: A material is something which an object is made of.

mainData.point1: Rubber is made from latex collected from rubber trees. It is an elastic material which can be easily stretched or compressed.

mainData.point1: Metals are found in the Earth's crust.

mainData.point1: The characteristics of metals are that it produce a metallic sound when hit, good conductors of heat and electricity, malleadble, flexible, ductile, hard and strong and are shiny.
