mainData.point1: Most metals are solid at room temperature.
mainData.point2: An exception is mercury which is a liquid at room temperature.

mainData.point1: Most metals are hard and strong. However, some metals have disadvantages in their pure form. For example, pure iron is very soft and rusts easily.
mainData.point2: So, alloys are preferred. An alloy is when a metal is mixed with other metals or non-metals. Alloys are usually stronger and have more useful properties than pure metals. For example, steel is an alloy made of iron and carbon. It is stronger than pure iron.

mainData.point1: Different metals are used for different uses.
mainData.point2: Aluminium are used for aircraft body, ship, car, train, bus, kitchen foil, cooking utensil.
mainData.point3: Copper are used for electrical wire, water pipe and mixed with other metals to form alloys.
mainData.point4: Iron and steel are used for nail, heavy machine, structures of pillars and bridges, cutlery, kitchenware and car body.
mainData.point5: Gold and silver are used for ornament and jewellery.
mainData.point6: Mercury is used for liquid in thermometers.

mainData.point1: Fabric refers to any materials made by weaving, knitting, crocheting or bonding.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: Fabric can be made from many materials. These materials come from four main sources: plants, animals, minerals and synthetic.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: Examples of materials that come from plants include cotton and linen.
mainData.point2: Cotton comes from the cotton plant. It is one of the oldest and most widely used materials in dress-making. It is cheap, cool and comfortable to wear and it creases easily unless treated with chemicals.
mainData.point3: Linen comes from the stem of the flax plant. It has a coarser texture than cotton. Natural linen creases easily unless treated with chemicals. Fine linen can be used to make delicate tablecloths while thick linen can be used to make suits and dresses.

mainData.point1: Examples of materials that come from animals include wool, silk and leather.
mainData.point2: Most wool comes from sheep, but come from goats and camels as well. The wool fibre that is sheared from the sheep's body is spun into woollen threads. The threads are then knitted or woven into cardigans, gloves or blankets. Wool is warm and suitable for winter wear. It is also elastic and crease-resistant. However, it will shrink if it is not washed carefully. It is also expensive.
mainData.point3: Silk comes from silkworms. The silkworms spins a long thread of silk around its own body to form a cocoon. When the cocoons are harvested, the farmer puts them in water. The silk threads loosen and the farmer then unwinds them. Silk is smooth and has an attractive shine. It is also cool to wear. However, good quality silk is very expensive and needs to be washed carefully. The material is used to make neckties, nightgowns and cheongsams.
mainData.point4: Leather comes from animal hides. It is dried and treated to make coats, jackets, bags and shoes.

mainData.point1: Examples of man made fibres are nylon and polyester.
mainData.point2: Nylon are made from chemicals obtained from coal, air and water.
mainData.point3: Polyester are made from chemicals obtained from petroleum.
mainData.point4: Both Nylon and polyester are strong fabrics. They do not shrink and the crease-resistant. However, they are not very absorbent.

mainData.point1: The characteristics of cloth are that is is light, soft, can be dyed in different colours, can be smooth or rough, can be cut into different shapes easily and are either natural or man-made.
Rock comes from the Earth's crust. It is the most abundant material on earth.
mainData.point2: Rocks are strong, hard and durable.

mainData.point1: Clay can be used to make bricks, flower pots, vases, bowls, cups and plates.

mainData.point1: Clay is also used together with limestone to make cement.

mainData.point1: Sand, gravel, cement and water are used to make concrete.

mainData.point1: Bricks, cement and concrete are used to build houses, roads and bridges.

mainData.point1: Glass is made from a mixture of sand, soda and limestone.
mainData.point2: Examples of uses of glass include test tube, light bulb, fish tank and flask.

mainData.point1: The characteristics of glass are that it is light, hard, brittle, poor conductor of heat and electricity and it is transparent.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: Glass is strong and non-reactive and it is a very useful material. Many household objects are made of glass. Drinking glasses, bowls and bottles are often made of glass. Light bulbs, mirrors, cathode ray tubes, windows, flasks, test tubes, lenses and other laboratory equipment are also made of glass.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: Materials can be classified based on their properties, for example, according to colour or texture.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: Materials are classified based on flexibility, buoyancy, electrical conductivity, thermal conductivity, magnetic property, degree to transparency to light, hardness and strength.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: The hardness of a matrial, also known as durability, refers to the ability of a material to withstand wear and tear.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: The hardness of a material is determined by scratching it with certain solids. A material can scratch all other materials that are softer than itself, but it cannot scratch those that are harder than itself.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: Examples of materials that are hard include metal, glass and wood. Titanium is one of the hardest metals; it is used in the construction of supersonic aircraft and artificial human bones.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: Examples of materials that are soft include rubber and paper.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: Plastics are materials that can be made hard, or soft and flexible.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: The strength of a material refers to the ability of the material to withstand force or support a heavy load without breaking or tearing.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: The strength of materials is relative. For example, a metal spoon is stronger than a plastic spoon while a plastic bag is stronger than a paper bag.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: Most pure metals are weak. However, they can be made by combining them with other metals or non-metals. For example, steel is made from iron and carbon and is much stronger than pure iron.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: The flexibility of a material refers to the ability of the material to bend without being damaged. Rubber is a material that is very flexible.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: Whether a substance sinks or floats in water actually depends on its density. For example, a pebble and a ball-bearing sink in water because they have a higher density than water. On the other hand, a piece of cork floats on water because it is less dense than water.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: Materials can be classified based on their degree of transparency to light, that it, how uch light they allow to pass through them.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.point1: There are three degrees of transparency to light.
mainData.point2: Transparent materials allows most light to pass through. An example is glass. It can be used for spectacle lens.
mainData.point3: Translucent materials allows some light to pass through. An example is frosted glass. It can be used for windows.
mainData.point4: Opaque materials does not allow light to pass through. An example is wood. It can be used as a table.

mainData.point1: Materials can also be classified according to their magnetic properties whether they are magnetic.
mainData.point2: Magnetic materials like iron and steel are attracted to magnets. They can be used to make doorstopper.
mainData.point3: Non-magnetic materials like wood are not attracted to magnets. It can be used to make a table.

mainData.point1: Thermal conductivity or heat conductivity refers to the ability to allow heat to pass through.
mainData.point2: Materials that are good conductors of heat can conduct heat very quickly and allow heat to pass through easily. An example is aluminium and steel. It can be used to make utensil.
mainData.point3: Insulators conducts heat poorly and does not allow heat to pass through easily. An example is wood. It can be made into a table.

mainData.point1: Electrical conductivity refers to the ability to conduct electricity to allow electricity to pass through.
mainData.point2: Materials that are good conductors of electricity conducts electricity and allows electricity to flow through easily. An example is copper. It can be made into an electrical wire.
mainData.point3: Electrical insulators does not conduct electricity well and does not allow electricity to flow through easily. An example is plastic. It can be made into the casing of a plug.

mainData.point1: There are many animals in our environment.
mainData.point2: Animals are living things and they need air, water and food to survive and can grow, move, respond to changes and reproduce
mainData.point3: Animals are not able to make their own food and thus depend on other living things of food.
mainData.point4: Animals have different sizes, colours and shapes, habitats, body movements, outer coverings, diets, modes of reproduction

mainData.concepts: Difference in Size, Colour and Shape
mainData.point1: Animals are different in size. For example, Killer whale and polar bear are large in size while beetle and mosquito are small in size.
mainData.point2: Animals are different in colour. For example, peacock and butterfly are more colourful looking while the crow and spider are more dull-looking.
mainData.point3: Animals are different in shape. Some animals have similar body shapes but are different in size, such as a crocodile and a lizard.

mainData.point1: Animals need homes for protection against bad weather such as the wind, cold, rain and sun and reproduction
mainData.point2: Habitats provide shelter for animals. Food and water are usually within easy reach.
mainData.point3: As different animals have different needs, their habitats are found in different places. There are two kinds of habitats, in water and on land. In water habitats consists of seas, rivers, lakes and ponds. On land habitats consists of trees, grasslands, caves and underground.
mainData.point4: The following are examples of animals that live on land.
mainData.point5: For example, squirrels and monkeys live on trees, zebras and giraffes live on grasslands, bata and bears live in caves ,and earthworms and rabbit live in underground burrows.
mainData.point6: There are also many animals that live in water. For example, sharks and whales live in the sea, ducks and geese live in lakes, crocodiles and crayfish live in rivers ,and water stick insects and pond skaters live in the pond
mainData.point7: There are some animals that live both on land and in water.
mainData.point9: Animals may be taken away from their natural habitats and placed in man-made homes.
mainData.point10: Example, Zoos, aquariums, farms and our homes
mainData.point11: There are four kinds of food and animal products from farm animals which are food, milk, egg and others.
mainData.point12: Food consists of chicken, pig, cow, duck, prawn and fish.
mainData.point13: Milk consists of cow and goat.
mainData.point14: Egg consists of chicken, duck and quail
mainData.point15: Others consists of silkworm for its silk, sheep for its wool and cow for its leather.
mainData.point16: Some animals are kept on farms for food and animal products.
mainData.point17: Some animals are kept in aquariums and zoos so that we can view and study them.
mainData.point19: There are also some animals that are kept in our homes as pets.

mainData.point1: Animals can move from one place to another.
mainData.point2: They move about to look for food, water and shelter.
mainData.point3: They also move around to look for mating partners.
mainData.point4: They move to escape from their predators and poachers.
mainData.point5: They move about in many different ways.
mainData.point6: The movements of animals differ because each animal has its own unique body structure that suits the living environment.
mainData.point8: Hopping. Animals that move about by hopping usually have strong legs. Example, toad and grasshopper
mainData.point9: Flying. Most animals with wings can fly. They fly by flapping their wings. Example, butterfly and eagle
mainData.point10: Crawling. Animals that crawl move about by using their legs and with their bodies very near or touching the ground. Example, tortoise and caterpillar.
mainData.point11: Climbing. Animals that move about by climbing have specially designed limbs, sharps claws and strong beaks to help them climb trees. Example, squirrel and koala bear.
mainData.point12: Gliding. Animals with no legs move about by gliding. They use their body muscle to glide. Example, snail and snake
mainData.point13: Swimming. Some animals make use of their fins, tails, bodies and legs to swim in the water. Example, seal and angelfish
mainData.point14: Many animals can move about in more than one way.
mainData.point15: Man. Walk, run, hop, skip, crawl and swim.
mainData.point16: Tiger. Walk, run, jump, skip, climb and swim.

mainData.concepts: The body of every animal is covered with a layer of skin.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Different animals have skins which are different in colour, thickness and texture.
mainData.point1: Animals have skins that are different in colour. Example, some dogs are black and some are white.
mainData.point2: Animals have skins that are of different thickness. Example, chickens have soft and thin skins, while cows have thick and tough skins. Example, snakes have smooth dry skins, while crocodiles have rough skins.
mainData.point3: Animals have skins that are of different textures. Example, snakes have smooth dry skins, while crocodiles have rough skins.

mainData.concepts: Some animals make use of the special patterns and colours  on their skin to blend in with their surrounding environment. This is called camouflage.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: There are some animals that have outer coverings on their skins.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Outer coverings are important to animals.
mainData.point1: Outer coverings keep them warm, help them fly, protect them, beautify them and camouflage them.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: There are four different types of outer coverings.
mainData.point1: The four are hair, feathers, scales and shells.
mainData.point2: Mammals have a layer of hair on their skin. This layer of air includes wool, bristles and fur. The amount, length and texture of this hair vary according to the natural conditions of the mammals' habitats. The hair keeps the body warm by trapping air in it to prevent its body heat from being lost to the surroundings. Example, polar bears and sheep have a thick coat of hair, while pigs and elephants have a thin layer of hair.
mainData.point3: Birds have a layer of feather on their skins. Young birds have small and fluffy feathers called down feathers to keep them warm. Older birds have flight feathers which besides keeping them warm, also enable them to fly. The feathers also protect the birds from getting wet on rainy days and in water. Example, goose and swan. Some male birds have bright, colourful feathers to attract their female counterparts. Example, peacocks and roosters have colourful feathers to attract their mating partners.
mainData.point4: Fish and reptiles have scales on their bodies. Scales are hard and tough. They protect the animals and help to prevent the body fluids of reptiles from dying. Example, codfish, garoupa, snake, lizard and crocodile.
mainData.point5: Some animals have shells to protect them from harsh environments and their predators. Example, crab, lobster, prawn, tortoise, snail and clam.

mainData.concepts: There are some animals that do not have any outer coverings on their skins. Example, squid, octopus, frog and earthworm.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Some of these animals have skins that help them breathe. Others have shell-like skins to protect them from harm.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Animals cannot make their own food. They depend on other living things for food.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Different animals have different eating habitsl. They are classified into three groups.
mainData.point1: The three eating habits are herbivores, carnivores and omnivores.
mainData.point2: Herbivores are animals that eat plants only.
mainData.point3: Different herbivores eat different parts of a plant. Example, horses, hippopotamuses and snails eat leaves and grasses. Bats, parrots and squirrels eat fruits, seeds and nuts of plants. Bees, butterflies and hummingbirds eat pollen grains or drink the nectar of flowers.
mainData.point4: Carnivores are animals that eat other animals only.
mainData.point5: The characteristics of carnivores are sharp and strong teeth or beak and claws, moves quickly, strong eyesight, strong build and highly sensitive sense of smell.
mainData.point6: Examples of carnivores include leopards, wolves, tigers, lions, crocodiles, great white sharks and eagles.
mainData.point7: Some carnivores eat only insects. They are known as insectivores.
mainData.point8: Examples of insectivores are lizards, bats and frogs.
mainData.point9: Omnivores are animals that eat both plants and other animals. Example, ostriches eat seeds, grains, insects, lizards etc. Raccoons eat nuts, fruits, insects, frogs, etc.

mainData.concepts: When animals have young, we say they reproduce.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Animals reproduce to avoid becoming extinct and to ensure the survival of their own kind.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Animals have two modes of reproduction.
mainData.point1: Laying eggs on land and in water or giving birth to young alive one at a time or a few at a time.
mainData.point2: Animals that reproduce by laying eggs have their young hatched from eggs. Some animals lay their eggs on land. These eggs have hard shells to protect them. Example, turtle and beetle. Some animals use their body warmth to incubate their eggs. Example, turkey, swan and penguin. Other animals lay their eggs in soil and sand and allow the warmth of the sun to incubate them. Example, crocodile, iguana and turtle. Some animals lay their eggs in water. These eggs usually do not have shells. Example, frog, fish and salamander. Eggs laid in water are usually large in numbers as many of  them may be eaten up by other animals.
mainData.point3: Some animals give birth to their young one at a time. Example, zebra and whale. Others give birth to their young a few at a time. Example, lion and rabbit. Mammals usually give birth to their young alive. However, the platypus and the spiny anteater are exceptions; they lay eggs.

mainData.concepts: The young of animals usually resemble their parents and differ only in size. Example, elephant, goat, giraffe, dolphin and crocodile.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: The young of some egg-laying animals do not look like their parents.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: However, as these young grow and develop, they undergo changes and will eventually look like their parents. The process of the change is called metamorphosis.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Many animals take care of their young. They feed their young, protect them from danger and predators and teach them skills needed for survival.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Example, both the male and the female eagles take care of their eaglets. As soon as the first egg is laid, the female and the male take turns to incubate. During the first four weeks after hatching, one of the parents (usually the female) broods the babies to keep them warm almost all the time, especially when the weather is cool. When the weather is hot and sunny, one or both of the parents shade the babies. The parents bring food to the nest 1 to 8 times per day to feed the babies. When a baby eagle fledges (loses its fluffy down feathers and grows flying feathers), a parent will hover over the nest and flap its wings and patiently teach it to fly.

mainData.concepts: Some animals do not take care of their young.
mainData.point1: Example, turtle, frog and butterfly.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Animals around us differ from one another in body shapes and sizes, their living habitats, and the way they move. However, some of them do share similar characteristics.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: These similarities enable us to classify them into groups.
mainData.point1: Vertebrates are animals with backbone and invertebrates are animals without backbones.
mainData.point2: Animals can also be grouped as cold-blooded or warm-blooded animals.
mainData.point3: Body temperature in cold blooded animals changes according to the surroundings. Example, insect, fish, reptile and amphibian.
mainData.point4: Body temperature in warm blooded animals does not vary much, whether or not the temperature of the surroundings changes. Example, bird and mammal.

mainData.point1: Most fish either live in salt water (marine) or fresh water. Example, Seahorse, angel, guppy and shark
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: There are many types of fish but there are certain characteristics that classify them as a group.
mainData.point1: The common features are eye, mouth, gill cover, dorsal fin, scale, tail, pectoral fin, anal fin and pelvic fin.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Most fish have fins to help them swim, balance and steer their bodies in water.
mainData.point1: The tail or caudal fin is used to propel the fish through water.
mainData.point2: The pectoral fin is used for steering the body of the fish.
mainData.point3: The pelvic fin helps the fish to maintain a balance.
mainData.point4: In some fish, the dorsal fin extends and joins the tail fin.

mainData.concepts: The body shapes of fish are quite varied. This is because fish have developed their bodies to suit their habitats for survival reasons. For example, fast-moving fish like the sharks have streamlined bodies to help them swim more easily while stingrays have flat bodies to help them look for food along the seabed.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: The bodies of most fish are covered with scales which overlap in one direction.
mainData.point1: The scales serve to protect the fish and to minimise friction when the fish are swimming in the water.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Some fish like the mudfish and catfish have no scales. Instead, they are protected by a tough leathery skin. Also, most fish are covered with a layer of mucus. It makes them slimy and are, therefore, difficult to grasp.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Fish have eyes but no eyelids. This is why they appear to be awake all the time. However, they do have periods of rest when their metabolic rate slows down.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Most fish breathe in the water using gills. Gills are found under the gill cover.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Water enters the fish through its mouth and as the fish closes its mouth, the water is forced to pass over the gills. As water flows between the gills, dissolved oxygen in the water is taken in through the gills. At the same time, carbon dioxide given out by the fish dissolves in the water which then flows out of the gills under the gill cover.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Some fish like the mudskipper can survive out of the water for a few hours because they can retain water in their mouths and can breathe in air through their skin.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Most fish reproduce by laying eggs. However, some fish, like guppies, sharks and swordtails give birth to their young alive.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Most fish do not take care of their young.

mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Birds are warm-blooded vertebrates. Like other animal groups, they also have distinct characteristics.
mainData.point1: They are crown, beak, breast, belly, claw, leg, wing, feather.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: They have feathers to keep them warm, protect their bodies and help them fly. Some birds have colourful feathers that help them attract their mating partners.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: All birds have wings, but only those with strong muscles and special lightweight skeletons are able to fly. Examples of birds that are flightless include the ostrich, kiwi and penguin.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Different birds have different kinds of feet. Their feet are adapted to suit their habitats for various reasons.
mainData.point1: There are six kind of feet. They are swimming, climbing, wading, grasping, perching and scratching.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Birds have no teeth but have beaks. Thier beaks are adapted for their feeding habits.
mainData.point1: The first kind is a seed-eating beak. An example is the parrot.
mainData.point2: The second kind is an insect-eating beak. An example is the sparrow.
mainData.point3: The third kind is a probing beak. An example is the hummingbird.
mainData.point4: The fourth kind is a flesh-eating beak. An example is the eagle.
mainData.point5: The fifth kind is a straining beak. An example is the goose.
mainData.point6: The sixth kind is a spearing beak. An example is the kingfisher.

mainData.concepts: All birds reproduce by laying eggs. Their eggs have hard shells. They usually lay their eggs in a nest and use their body warmth to incubate the eggs. Birds take care of their young until they grow up and become independent.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Some mammals live on land while some live in water.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Mammals breathe through their lungs. As such, mammals that live in water have to come up to the surface of the water for air.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Mammals have an outer covering of hair on their bodies to keep them warm. The amount of hair on each mammals varies. It depends on the living environment of the mammals. For example, polar bears have very thick hair while pigs have very little hair.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Female mammals feed their young with milk. This milk is produced by the mammary glands.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: All mammals have two pairs of limbs. However, for some mammals, their front limbs have been adapted for other users.
mainData.point1: Example, the front limbs of bats and seals have been adapted. They are used for flying and swimming respectively.
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: There are three main types of mammals.
mainData.point1: Placentals are mammals who have their babies developed inside the females. The body receives nourishment from its mother until it is ready to live outside the mother's body.
mainData.point2: Marsupials are pouched mammals. The female gives birth to its young when it is still undeveloped and keeps it inside its pouch. The newborn then continues to develop until it is ready to live on its own. Example, kangaroo and koala.
mainData.point3: Egg laying mammals reproduce by laying eggs. Example, spiny anteater and platypus.

mainData.concepts: All insects have a body that is divided into three parts: the head, the thorax and the abdomen. Each part is further divided into segments, but only the segments on the abdomen can be seen clearly.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: All insects have three pairs of jointed legs. Each pair of legs is attached to one segment on the thorax.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Each insect has a pair of jointed feelers called antennae on its head. The antennae give the insect a sense of smell and touch.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: An insect's body is protected by an outer covering of a layer of hard skin called the cuticle or the exoskeleton. It gives the insect its shape and protects its soft body.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Most insects have two pairs of wings. The wings are attached to the second and third segments of the thorax. Examples of such insects are the dragonfly and butterfly.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: However, some insects such as the mosquito use only one pair of wings to fly. The second pair of wings is used for balancing themselves.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: For some insects, such as the ladybird, the first pair of wings is thick. They form hard protective shields for the insects. There are also some insects which do not have wings and therefore cannot fly. Examples include the silverfish and the ant.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Insects reproduce by laying eggs and their young hatch from these eggs. Most of the time, the young will go through some changes before they eventually look like their parents.
mainData.point1: Empty Cell
mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: Some insects, like the cockroach and the grasshopper, have young that resemble the adult. They are only smaller in size and have no wings.

mainData.point2: Empty Cell

mainData.concepts: There are some invertebrates such as the spider, millipede and woodlouse that are not considered insects. They have segmented bodies, but have more than six jointed legs.
